number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Amazing game.Even though you are alone the entire time, the island you are stranded on really feels alive.  This game has the best simulation of a natural environment that I have ever felt.  You have no HUD, instead having to rely on paying attention to visual and audio cues from your character and your journal.I spent 23 hours on my first playthrough just living in the world, trying to map out the island, and trying to collect all the plants on the island.  In those 23 hours, I was never bored and was frequently on the edge of my seat.  Speaking of mapping, that is one of my favourite things about the game.  Once you understand how it works, it becomes a game in itself.  If you are the obsessive compulsive type, you will love travelling all over the island to get every spot mapped out.Your goal in the game is to discover a cure for a plague that you and the outside world are stricken with.  You do this by researching plants and finding clues scattered over the island.  But really, I just had fun being on the island, it is an incredible simulation.  Even the clouds are amazing, you could just sit there watching them go by and trying to see pictures in them.I should probably mention the controls.  Some have said that your character moves like he's on ice skates and slides around everywhere.  I didn't have a problem with this, your character is sick and not some olympic athlete like in every other game out there.  Falling down a hill can be one of the most dangerous things in this game and I think that is a good thing.  You really are a normal person suffering from a sickness and you are always vulnerable in this game.This is a fairly slow paced game that requires you to pay attention to your character and surroundings in a different way than any other and I think that makes it well worth playing.Oh, and make sure you download the community patch, I didn't play without it but it sounds like it makes a huge difference.  I experienced a couple of crashes even with the community patch but they weren't a big deal.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												This game opens with a very interesting premise, you have a disease and you must cure yourself.  The landmass you find yourself on has lots of materials to turn into possible cures, but you need to discover it all yourself.Gameplay: 7 / 10The crafting mechanic is slightly obtuse, but is somewhat novel in combining plants and other found ingredients together to create healing and other potions.  The map for this game is very unique, you don't get an auto-map like most games, you have to discover and then plot your points using 3 waypoints, so that you can use cartography to map where precisely something is on the map.  It does this for you of course, but it is an interesting and new take on in-game maps.  The fighting mechanic is sorely lacking though.  When you finally come upon your first fight, you will most likely die, and then wonder how you are supposed to prevent yourself from dying.  The game gives you no help here, and largely I guess you are supposed to just run and hide, although rocks and other refuse can help you avoid animals.Graphics: 5 / 10Nothing fancy here, the environment is much like many other games, there is a lot of detail in the chemical lab and the grass looks neat.  But nothing here wowed me beyond the panoramic views you can see from vantage points.Sound: 5 / 10Nothing fancy here, the music doesn't take away from the experience and largely gives you a nice time.Overall: 6 / 10I enjoyed playing the game until animals started going after me, at that point I lost interest because I didn't know the game even had combat, was woefully unprepared and just died.  Overall though it was a positive experience until I died.

number of helpful: 25 of 42 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Its an interesting game but definitely not without some concerns that let the game down.The ideas is good and at the start its quite entertaining, but after a few hours of wandering around trying to figure out what your meant to be doing it get a little tedious.Our lead character stumbles around lost, so weak he can't carry more than three flowers and any hill or bump greater than 10degrees will sent him into a tail spin.He can only carry one item like a knife or axe, at a time and half the time he'll randomly drop it or throw it away anyway.  No big deal really because they don't seem to be of any use bsides waving around when the bunyip monkey monster comes around. You can't actually attack anthing.The biggest let downs IMO is the issues with the day night cycles and the so called mapping.  Both these things in particular turn a slow paced novel game into a boring frustrating slow paced game.It seems to be night for a far greater time than day, and in the dark you are literally in total blackness. Even using torches etc are near useless so the only thing you can do is wait. And wait and wait and wait, until daylight slowly comes.  Even during the day, it can all of a sudden become near total darkness because its getting cloudy, or its an eclipse or whatever reason.At night you occasionaly run into the bunyip monkey monster that come at you, sends your heart rate faster and faster and most of the time you just run and hope! I get the feeling this "monster" was put in as a last minute item to try and add some sense of fear. You can't seem to kill it or anything and seems out of place, especially considering theres no other living creatures besides some bugs and birds in the distance. The mapping system is the second let down.  its a good idea where you need to triangulate points from known landmarks etc but is a long, tedious and frustrating affair. 90 percent of the game is simply trying to work out where you are and where your going. Trying to make a map, 1 small section at a time. The game isn't all bad as such, but is definitely not suited for everybody. I quite enjoyed it at the start and the collection of plants etc to make medicine etc is a neat idea. Unfortunately that is all it has. Besides drinking, and taking medicine, then thats it for gneral survival. You don't have to eat, or hunt, or build shelters.  Even sleep is just a way to speed through the night if your lucky enough to be near a bed when night falls, and to save your game.Its the sort of game where every now and then I'll probably have a bit of a tinker with it, but its definately not the sort of game I'd recomend to anyone looking for thrills, excitement and adventure etc.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I rate the game Miasmata 3.5/5. Pretty good..if you have a lot of patience and enjoy games which feature fairly quiet, peaceful natural surroundings.This, being the second game in which I've played as a person who is ill (The first being Far Cry 2) is a slow-paced, generally peaceful, first person perspective survival game wherein you must maneuver your weakened, occasionally feverish character around a rugged series of tropical and subtropical islands to find various fungi and flowers and then bring them back to various scattered laboratories to find out what properties they have in an ongoing attempt to get yourself cured. If you walk too fast or (unlike in Skyrim) walk down a hill which is too steep you may end up running and then falling which will decrease your health, may cause your fever to worsen (because you have over-exerted yourself I guess) and you will drop everything you are carrying and may not be able to easily find it again. Also, in this game your character can get exhausted, dehydrated and, if you make him swim for too long, may even drown. Going for a long time without sleep will also weaken your health. Standing around in the beautifully rendered tropical rain however has no effect on your health whatsoever. You never seem to have to eat anything though if you did have to, the game probably would have taken forever to finish.This game is fairly long and requires great patience as simply making your character walk down a hill without falling down can be a challenge in itself. To put it another way, trying to get around in this game is probably a lot like being really old (except you can move more quickly than the elderly). If that wasn't enough of a challenge already, there are carnivorous creatures (they aren't creepy though as they look a lot like panthers with horns glued onto their heads and odd, hand-like feet) on the island which occasionally show up to hunt you. I don't think the creature was actually one but maybe several solitary creatures which live on the island (like mountain lions or something). But take heart, as you find cures for yourself your condition improves and with it, your ability to more easily move around the islands.The game's plot does have some loose threads. You can find old journal entries which suggest that one of the island's inhabitants went crazy and, given the way the corpses around the island apparently died (with a knife stuck into each them). However this murderer never materializes. I guess he ran off into the jungle and killed himself...or maybe he somehow was transformed one of the cat-creatures which occasionally stalks you to the loud sound of your beating heartbeat. There are also two distinct types of ruins in the island setting of this game but nothing can be found out about either group who built the ruins. Indeed, the ruins exist primarily to serve as mere landmarks to help mapping the islands easier. This game often hints at a more complex and detailed plot the sum-total explanation of which is frustratingly not to be found anywhere in this game. Still this game in all its interest and unusual gameplay and beauty is amazing for when we consider it appears to have been put together by just two people (brothers I think) over the course of what I heard was four years.Now that you know the gist of what Miasmata is, it's time to break down what the pros and cons of this game are.Good things about this game:+This game is often remarkably beautiful, particularly if you enjoy the natural beauties which this world has to offer. The tropical and sub-tropical island setting has lots of wonderful sunsets, trees and nifty rays of light filtering through the trees. The colors are vibrant and the reflections off of water are pretty also. The rain effect was particularly well done and better by far than the awful rain effect in the 2010 version of Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit. The rain in Miasmata was wonderful and other game developers should take a look at how the rain was done here. That said, the overall graphical detail of this game is rather mediocre.+This game relies heavily on the natural sounds of the world with sparse and almost entirely instrumental music playing only very rarely. The sounds are done very well except in one situation.+Overall this game was rewarding and interesting through to the end. A true and beautiful work of art. While not the most moving or emotional game ever it was definitely fun and the sense of mystery never went away (because unfortunately, many things were never fully explained). By the time I was done with the game I was ready for it to be over and so it lasted just the right length of time for me to feel fulfilled and refreshed by this game's unusual first person perspective survival concept. This game was a true adventure.Mediocre things about this game:+/-The graphics do tend to be simple. Your limbs are fairly blocky. Indeed, most objects tend to be fairly blocky when viewed up-close. The clouds are often curiously tinged with brown and when combined with the intermittent atmospheric haze and the fact that the fog in this game looks a lot more like smoke it accidentally feels as though the islands are supposed to be on fire somehow. The islands you are wandering around in are not supposed to be on fire but it often sure does look as though they must be.+/-The carnivorous creatures can, from some angles, almost look cute due to their cat-like appearance. You are clearly supposed to find them terrifying but they aren't. They just seem more like some sort of weirdly mutated, previously unknown species of jungle cat which sees you as potential prey. At the same time though, this lends an added air of realism to the environment.+/- Finding the plants you need to concoct a cure is very difficult and made even more difficult by the presence of the creature hunting you whenever you are near a plant that you absolutely need to grab.+/-You can only save your game at certain geographic locations but these locations are so numerous that saving my game was never much of a problem.Bad things about this game:-The controls are definitely difficult. It often feels, especially early on that your character must be just learning how to use roller skates which have somehow become permanently attached to his feet. This roller skate feeling never really left either but as I progressed through the game I found myself learning how to handle the character better, even putting him into controlled slides occasionally to get down slopes more quickly. Some of the other controls (picking stuff up with your right hand without dropping stuff in your left hand for example) were also a bit clunky.-The one time when the sound is not good is when a carnivorous creature is hunting you and your heartbeat sounds WAY TOO LOUDLY in your ears. This sound didn't increase my sense of tension. It merely increased my sense of irritation. I often wanted to avoid the creatures not so much because they were scary but because i didn't want the loud heartbeat sound to intrude on the quiet ambience of the game more than it had to.-Once you have a carnivorous cat creature's attention it is VERY HARD to hide and get it to go elsewhere. Sometimes I would hide and it would just wait forever for me to come out even though it couldn't see me.-I wish this game had more scary moments or had capitalized more on the numerous scary moments it was sort of trying to have. I wonder what this game would have been had it been somehow done with the far more beautiful game engine used in Far Cry 3 somehow. The graphics often seemed a bit dated. Still, Far Cry 3 was made by a team of people which formed a list longer than my arms and Miasmata is an amazing achievement for what seems to have been just 2 people.

												Just.... ♥♥♥♥.Miasmata is one of the games that I wanted to play ever since release but I just kept on waiting and waiting for a sale, and when it was on sale, I still didn't pick it up since I was skeptical and bought other games instead... But when I finally did buy it... It completely blew my mind. Miasmata is one of my favorite indie games of all time and shows that you can make a different game with a low budget without vomiting some "philosophical" nonsense on it to make it seem legit. The game is ridiculously atmospheric and immersive and it completely sucks you in. The only "downside" is that it's a one time experience. Once you finish the game, even if you're into achievements hunting, there isn't much to return to. The appeal of the game is exploration and once the island is explored, well, yeah. content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
Maismata - a game reviewExperienceThis, I feel, is the most important part and the best reason for playing this game. The looks, your movements, the sounds, the story and the mechanics all work together to make this an interesting and immersive experience. You feel that the character, you, isn't doing well, that you're often exhausted and have to fight both the exotic environment as well as your illness. You huff and puff at any exertion, thirst and untreated fevers impair your vision and coordination, falls will often disorient you and even finding out just where you are is something of a chore. Day-to-day survival is work here, giving you a sense of vulnerability, compounded by the fear of the Creature.I'll give each of these a closer look below. LooksThis is a very good-looking game, most of the time. There are a few graphic oddnesses, like the arms and hands that, while important and immersive can't help looking a little awkward at times. Texture pop-in and the sometimes very 'grainy' water are easily forgivable sins, seeing that most everything else works very well. Special mention should be made of the day and night cycle. Not only do dawns and sunsets look fantastic, as do the rays of sunlight filtered through the trees, they also actually work. Looking toward a brighter light, like the sun or a torch, will make dark areas even darker and more difficult to navigate. Nights are very dark indeed, there being nothing more than the moon and stars to light your way. Your lighter is a decent emergency light and burning twigs or a torch will properly light up your immediate area, helping you find your way to some sort of shelter.MovementI suspect that many will find moving around in this game to be an awkward business, much unlike the fluid movements in other First Person games. Moving forwards is generally fine but try any looking-left-while-strafing-right to look around while moving or a very quick turn and you're in for a surprise. It would seem that Robert can't run sideways as fast as he can run forwards. This shouldn't be the shock it is, since most people can't. You also have momentum to contend with - running downhill can be a very bad idea and may easily run you right over a ledge into a nasty fall. Climbing hills is a slow to laborious process which is further influenced by your current state. Thirst and fever will make you weaker and slower, making progress more difficult.If all this sounds awkward and off-putting, you can rest assured that there are good and design-conscious reasons behind every seeming impediment.SoundThe soundscape of Miasmata is fairly minimal but well implemented. There are near-constant ambient noises, such as wind, rustles, trickling or rushing water, bird-calls, crashing waves or rain, but next to no score. There's music in the game, to be sure, but it's held back to mark certain locations or the odd special moment.  Your footfalls have their own sounds, in keeping with whatever surface you're on, which is a nice touch. Loose rocks and crackling twigs could have a few more samples though, being a bit repetetive.MechanicsA brief look at some of the different ways things are done in the game.Medicines are "synthesized" in the labs around the Island, using one or two plants for each new type. Each plant first has to be found and examined. How to do this is clearly explained in the first few notes you find and works well. The process does get repetetive but the animations can be interrupted. A few more different animations would be nice to have. Notes scattered around the island will tell you where to look for crucial elements and thus give you a good incentive to travel all over the place.Cartography is a large and important feature in the game. You have precious little idea of where you are, most of the time, since you have to 'draw' the map on your own. This is accomplished by triangulating your current position, using your compass and known landmarks. Distant and unknown landmarks can be triangulated by moving between two known positions and marking them on the map. Much like in real life. Well implemented, with a chance of a minor 'exploit' as a handy shortcut.Time does flow here, as shown by your watch and the well made day/night-cycle. This gives you a sense of urgency, since being caught out after dark has the very real consequense of easily losing your way to that shelter and bed. Unfortunately, the sense of urgency is diminished by the fact that you don't see a definite progression of your illness, that you can stay alive on water and medicine indefinitely.The Creature is a somewhat mysterious and certainly threatening presence on the island. It can turn up at nearly any time and will likely send chills down your spine as you hear the sudden thump of your own heartbeat, reminding you of your precarious situation. There are techniques and medicinal boosts that can help you avoid being found, which is a good thing, seeing as you're in no shape to fight this beast. Well done, overall, but it does occasionally get stuck in a loop, which can be annoying.StoryI intentionally left this for last, since it's in the manual and of litte importance. When starting the game, you're placed in the shoes of Robert Hughes, a plague-stricken scientist, stranded on an unknown island, in search of a cure. Precisely why a name is mentioned is something of a mystery, since the who of you is of utter insignificance to anything that happens in the game. (Here the developers missed a chance to involve female players a little more.) The more imortant words are 'stranded', made evident by your bloody hands and the wrecked boat beside you and 'plague-stricken', as you'll notice shortly.Fever, thirst, brutally murdered scientists, mysterious messages, baffling notes, helpful discoveries, rain, darkness, swamps, glorious sunsets, coluorful fungi and more plants than you can shake a burning twig at will help and hinder and baffle you on your journey. Your goal, ultimately, is to find the cure and escape this island. The cure is to be found among the rich flora of the island, which you will research, annotate and cook up various medicines from. Some will just be a temporary stay of your recurring fevers and some will give you more lasting effects. To help your progress, you'll find the notes of the expedition scattered around in their huts and tents.Escaping the island, alive, will not be easy.There are some missed opportunities for exposition and deepening the story, such as conspiracies or cover-ups that are just hinted at, the obvious mystery of the murders which could be better developed and the odd and disconcerting Creature.RecommendationAll in all, I found this to be a very rewarding exerience. I thoroughly enjoyed the lush environments of the island, the often beautiful vistas opening up in front of me as I clear the crest of a hill, the deep dark of the nights and the heart-pounding fear of being found by the Creature. I even liked the work of mapping my progress around the island, since it added both realism and a feeling of accomplishment set against the helplessness of being lost.Kudos and a hearty 'Well done!' to the brothers of IonFX.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I got a good 12 hours of exploration and adventure!Pros :-A truly beautiful game. Worth it just to get lost in it.-Once you get used to movement, it actually becomes an extra challenge just to move up and down slopes. Its quite fun!-I would get giddy with excitement whenever I'd discover a new plant and would hurry back to the lab to check it out!-Tons of different drugs to craft and use-The creature won't appear often, but when the character's heart starts pumping, yours will too!-The creature acts in a believable way! There are several different ways to deal with it... some ending with your death.-After trekking in the wilderness, you truly get a feeling of satisfaction when you discover an outpost.-You are completely free to explore at your leasure in any direction. The island is also massive!-The cartography system is awesome. Later in the game I had a lot of fun mapping out the entire island.-When night falls it gets very dark... which is very scary. Add to it the monster on the prowl and you have a bit of horror.Cons-Character is a bit too prone to falling and tripping down slight hills. It gets annoying/frustrating.-Some areas won't be of much use later on -  more quantity over quality (vast areas with just trees, useless ruins, etc)-Ruins are a bit of a dissapointment : there are no secrets nor lore to it. Who built them? You won't know.-There is a bit of a tease with ''Psychotic episodes'' and ''hallucinations'' being mentioned in a paper, but it doesn't happen. If you let the fever worsen you just die.-Survival is unrealistically easy - no need to hunt nor eat, and resting in a shoddy cot in a tent will cure you of heavy fever. Taking pills also instantly makes you better. I kinda wish it worked like that IRL.-The ending is pretty sad and disappointing. Didn't feel like my efforts payed off. All in all, I'd say the pro far outweigh the cons. It is very impressive that two guys made this game from scratch!If you like exploration, discovery, ambiance, science with only a little bit of scare, then you will really enjoy this one.Wholeheartedly recommend.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2013
												Miasmata is a great idea with a somewhat flawed execution. You're a scientist on an island looking for a cure. To find this cure you have to find plants and create potions, while triangulating landmarks to create your own map of the island. The island is huge and you're free to go wherever you want, as long as you can keep yourself alive. You have to be careful that you don't dehydrate, drown, get killed by a creature (I haven't encountered it myself yet) or that you take your medicine in time. The game is played from a first person perspective, which actually works quite alright, but walking and running (and especially stopping/slowing down) can be awkward and clumsy. It tries to be realistic by slowing down your character when climbing up the hills or speeding up when you're heading downwards. Most of the times it seems random and I've lost count of how many times I've fallen.You're also allowed to carry a maximum of 3 different plants at the same time, and you can't carry more than one of the same plant. So most of the times you have to make multiple trips. However, there are cabins scattered across the island. These cabins allow you to transfer your plants between any of them, which helps, but limiting the amount of plants you can carry is still a bit frustrating. On the other hand, it does create a certain tension so I guess there's something to be said for it. Especially traveling when it's dark is not recommended, because it can get pitchblack without any torches. And then there's this creature I keep hearing about...So, I'm having some mixed emotions here. I guess I shall be taking my journal and compass, and enter the world once more to see if my opinion changes for the better... or for the worse.[Rating: 73/100]

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Miasmata is an absolute gem of an indie game. I have been following this game for quite a while, and now I can finally say I own it. Created by just two people from IonFX, the game does deliver on what it is set out to be. It is not a horror game, it is a survival exploration game where you explore an island, known only to you as EdenYou play Robert Hughes, a man who was exiled and is stricken with plague. You have to find three agents; Agent X, Agent Y and Agent Z to form the cure to cure your strickened fever. You have to travel across the huge map of Eden and find specific plants and fungi to form the basic components to make the cure. However, you are not alone. There is a creature that is watching you and hunting you down in the deep dense forests of the dangerous island of EdenOverall, the game is fantastic. The game does not hold you're hand at all. No checkpoints, no objectives, nothing. It just throws you in and you have to discover what the island holds yourself. Although the game's graphics aren't the best, they do deliver and you can play this game on any piece of modern hardware Although frequent pop ups of the environment do ruin a bit the feel for the game, the game's graphics deliver. The music, what little there is, is very good and fits perfectly with the atmosphere of the game. However, the game heavily relies on sound effects and yes, the game does deliver this perfectly. If you want a true experience, play the game with headphonesAs said before, the game does not hold your hand. You have to discover the island for yourself, hence, the game can get boring and sometimes too difficult as the map system, which uses cartography, is a bit annoying and frustrating, especially when it comes to unknown locations. If you hadn't updated your map or found letters and documents that update you're map, then you will be a sitting duck and lost completely. Although the game does offer a compass to help, which in some cases, it does. Sometimes, you will just be lost for hours. For me personally to find the closest campsite without the use of the map, it took me roughly an hour. The map is huge for this gameThe gameplay, although simple, all you have to do is explore the island and collect plants and fungi which then get added to your journal. Once you've found a campsite which has an experimentation table, you can experiment with the collected items to form basic or advanced medicine or agents for the cureAs mentioned previously, the main protagonist, Robert is stricken with plague and fever. Hence, he isn't that strong, and though I appreciate the people at IonFX for making it realistic, it does get quite annoying. When you run too much, he breathes too heavily which in turn can get annoying and can be a lure for the creature. You can't climb that high, hence he falls back when its too high, again, annoying and can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥when trying to run away from the creature and he falls too suddenly making you go into a fall animation which spins the camera like nobody's business making you lose the items you had, which in turn is annoying and a pain when trying to run away from the blasted creature. Also, you can only swim a certain amount, otherwise, thanks to his plague infested body, he will start to drown and die. Very annoyingThe creature, what a wonderful yet terrifying creature. The creature roams the island in search for you and will hunt you down. The only way you can avoid the creature is either by hiding or by distracting it. You cannot outrun it, its quicker than you and with the annoyance of your bloody plague, you can't get too far. The creature is scary and makes your heart pump a few times when you encounter it. But, the more and more you encounter it, especially when you have the last few ingredients of the cure, the more and more, the creature becomes annoying and a chore to find a place and hide. Don't get me wrong, the creature was a brilliant addition to the game, but good god can it get boring and frustrating. At first, before you find a specific drug, the only way you will only be notified if the creature is nearby is by the beating sound of Robert's heart. The stronger it gets, the closer the creature isOnce you have found a specific drug, the game will provide you with an indicator whilst crouched which will show a HUD system in which when white, the creature can't see you and red when it can see you. The stealth mechanic is okay, but not the best. Sometimes, when you're hiding and the HUD system says you're okay, the creaure can still see you and sometimes when the creature is really close to you and you can tell that it's seeing you, it ignores you completely. Also sometimes, the HUD system and sound effect did not work which made it even more frustratingIf you die by, fever, dehydration, drowning or killed by the creature. If you haven't recently saved, you're stuck. There is no quick save functionality and no checkpoints, the only way you can save is either by lighting a candle or lamp, or by sleeping which saves the game and these can only be found in campsitesThe game does offer a day and night cycle as well as a weather system, great additions to the game. However, at night, if you do not have a source of light, good luck looking where you are going as the night becomes pitch black and very scary. Robert only seems to drink water, no food, which does lose a bit of the realismThe game is fantastic, but is plagued with bugs, glitches and crashes. The amount of times the game crashed on me, I just wanted to give up. Sometimes during the menu, sometimes while playing. The game would just simply crash. Bugs and glitches too are annoying, sometimes Robert would get stuck on the environment as well as other minor bugsI wish the game would have fixed these issues. Also, the game does encounter some stuttering when trying to load some music or a piece of the environment, even sometimes crashing the game in the process...Miasmata is a fantastic game and a true indie gem, if only IonFX would have fixed some of the problems that the game had and gave some help to its player base, then this game would of been ten times better than what it is. But as it stands, the story is interesting, the graphics are good, music and sound effects well produced. Miasmata is one of those games you should pick, even if it is just for a couple of hours! RECOMMENDED :)  THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get "Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game", etc... So I have decided to make my own!)

content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												As my first Greenlight purchase, Miasmata left me speechless, really.Miasmata brings a new dimension to Adventure/Exploration games. It gathers true exploration, with bits of survival, and a unique way to draw your map progressively as you explore the massive island (seriously, it takes hours just to go round it) while randomly harassed by a mysterious monster.The sensation to be lost becomes a true reality. The feeling that everything around you looks the same, and that you can't distinguish the North from the South. Or the stressful moment when you see the sky getting darker, meaning you desperately need to find a tent or a cabin.The graphics are splendid, but make sure you have a decent computer, for the game is being pretty demanding. And what about those unforgettable light effects? They are astounding. Like, when you can't see any single thing at night, or when you're dazzled by the morning sun.If you want to live a real survival experience and explore beautiful forsaken places, just buy it!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Took me a little while to understand the mapping part of the game. You basically have to identify at least two man made structures (Building, statue, beacon) to pinpoint where you are on the map then find other unknown structures that are also in view and they then become known. You can now use those identified structures as map elements. Don't wander too far, try to keep these map markers in view and keep checking the map to add more pieces to it.The concoctions you can make are temporary ones or permanent ones. You can carry only one of each temporary type so don't bother making two basic medicines, just make one basic and one enhanced. The weapons seem practically useless so far, there is a beast that stalks you, attacking with knife or axe doesn't seem to bother it at all. Ducking into cover doesn't seem to help much but getting behind hard cover like a tree does.You have to drink quite often but fresh water is plentiful, yet in seven game days I haven't eaten anything so the finds of bananas and apples lying around don't seem to matter.Climbing even the gentlest of slopes can be difficult and it is super easy to go tumbling off and falling. Try hitting reverse when sliding down a hill to slow your descent, that helps. Save by lighting anything (beacon, candle, fire, lantern) or by sleeping and keep an eye on the time, right mouse button brings up a compass and wrist watch, when it gets dark...it gets REALLY dark! You can get lost very quickly at night or go falling off a cliff, we forget living as we do in towns and cities that street lighting however dim is still there, in this game there's you holding a piddling little lighter unless you find brush to use as a torch until it fizzles out a minute later.I am enjoying it immensely, yes it feels a little clumsy at times and low budget but the night time without a torch and no where near a camp confusion is very real, and then there's the beast tracking you, when you see it coming for you and you run, panic just sets in, fighting it doesn't do anything, just have to run or hide.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2013
												If you love filling in blank spaces on a map, scavenger-hunting map icons, humping the spacebar to climb hills... this is your game.It won't dazzle you with a lot of different mechanics, but what it does provide is unique. As far as I (suburban dude) can tell, it's an eye-opening wilderness hiking simulator, where you experientially learn how it's a seriously bad idea to set off on a trip without lots of daylight, a clear goal, a good map, and plenty of water.To be clear: the game doesn't lecture you about survival and navigation. Instead you get certain reflexes drilled into you after you stay out too late, run out of daylight, get lost and dehydrated, fall down a hill, stumble into a lake and drown. Since you can only save your game at certain locations, well, drowning after a day-long expedition is bad.The orienteering and cartography mechanics are just plain neat (and well-described elsewhere). The game provides a layer of goals and some mysterious opposition to deal with, but those aspects just add context to the exploration. It's nicely atmospheric and very zen at times. And occasionally scary.Keep in mind that this is an "indie game by 2 guys", but more often than not it's a better-designed package than you might expect from that. It's still a niche-audience thing, but outstanding if you're in that audience.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Miasmata is, in essence, a game of exploration; moreover, an exploration simulator. The devs went to great lengths to rethink gaming fundamentals such as mapping, stealth, even basic movement. These changes may spook a lot of players, but those that let go of traditional gaming conventions will discover a rich new genre of gaming.At the core of this game is the mapping system. Left to map out the environment yourself with a compass and triangulation, I often tell people interested in this game that it is a cartography simulator. While some find this method of mapping tedious, it brought about something both rare in games, and exciting: getting lost. I was often faced with decisions regarding how far to explore because getting lost sucked. The flip side was that finding your way back to someplace familiar provided an awesome feeling of accomplishment! Stealth comes into play when faced with an undefeatible predator. This mechanic was a rush. You have no indicator of where the predator is except that when it is near, your heart beats. Many hide now/ search later moments. Running like hell works often for a rush of adrenaline. Rushing towards a shack lit in candlelight while the beast is at your heels, then crouching in a corner hoping not to be noticed as you peek your head up to see if it's gone was a common thrill for me in this game.The movement has been criticized by a few (at least), but I really enjoyed the dev's take on it. Think: momentum.Your character starts off relatively weak, so often times you are left to risk walking down a steep looking hill or trying to rush up one. Walking down presents you with having to press the back button as a way to balance/ control your descent. Ascending requires taking a bit of a run to push your way up. Misjudging either causes a tumble which drops your items in hand and a big chance at getting a fever. Both a bit of a hassle. Mostly, this doesn't pose much of a problem, however when chased by the predator I found it exciting as hell. Split moment decisions risking death or losing that plant that took a bit to find provided a truly unique gaming experience.Wrap up: 14 y.o. into COD and hoping to play an indie FarCry? Pass. Enjoy discovery and exploration of both the gaming enviroment and new conventions? BUY NOW.CYA

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Miasmata is one of the more unique and engaging survival games I've encountered. The game pits you as a plague-striken botanist, exiled to a remote island where other unfortunate scientists have also been sent to discover a cure. You must continue their research in hope to escape the island alive.The gameplay pits you exploring the island to search for and study the local plant life in hopes of synthesizing an antidote. The island is lush with plants, wildlife, and significant landmarks. Research stations and outposts are scattered throughout the island, some containing clues, notes, and other pieces of information to aid your quest.Cautious travel throughout the land is imperative as darkness unfolds. The rolling hills can be unforgiving in your weakened state causing momentum to send you over the edge. Mapping is essential to your travel and the use of triangulation to pinpoint your location not only proves innovative, but really makes the overall gameplay feel like a genuine survival game. But don't linger around too long out in the darkness as a creature lurks in the distance watching your every move, thwarting your efforts to gather the necessary ingredients to improve your health.The graphics are pretty impressive; the different and distinct landscapes are breathtaking, and the shadowing as day transitions to night and back to day is amazing. The games includes fabulous musical scores as well. Overall, the game is really a unique experience. I'm still in awe that it was developed by only two individuals.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Please do not let the technical flaws of this game (of which there are plenty) turn you away from it. If you're the kind of person who can allow yourself to get completely immersed into a virtual world, look past those flaws and give this world a try.Yes, there are issues. The uphill/downhill momentum can at times feel a bit... overzealous. Graphical fidelity is all over the place - while the general environment and landscape looks beautiful from afar, certain ugly details are exposed given a close-up. Several Steam Achievements are broken. You should probably avoid Alt+Tabbing the game due to the dreaded "One Moment Please..." problem. Performance issues can bring the entire world to a complete standstill for several seconds at a time, and you'll eventually realize that the only thing that "no loading screens" really means is that loading can get you killed. As the game was made from scratch by a pair of brothers, this sort of stuff is to be expected. There is an unofficial community patch out there (along with other helpful game utilities), and I'd recommend that you check that out before taking things too far.But to be perfectly honest, since I decided to give this game another try after a near-year-long hiatus taken shortly after the intro, I'm thankful that I didn't pass it up. As one of those aforementioned people who can immerse themselves in games quite easily, I found a tension in this game that few other games have ever made me feel. That moment when I'm standing on the porch of my safehouse, barren map in-hand, building up the courage to take my first step into the unknown. That moment when I've got my headphones cranked up, and I'm crouch-walking through the forest, eyes peeled, my heart stopping at the crunch of every twig. That moment when all hell has broken loose and I've gone into a full-on panic-sprint, knowing that my only chance at survival is to put myself at the complete mercy of the terrain and just run. Those moments are gaming gold.Miasmata has a bit of a learning curve; anybody who has played it can attest to that. For all of the things that this game can give to you, there are just as many things that it will leave you to take for yourself. You'll struggle with movement. You'll struggle with cartography. You'll leave the house a bit too late one night and find yourself completely lost, hopeless, and staring death in the face. But give this game your time and your effort, and it will give you a completely unreplicated experience in return.Save early, save often. Stay alert, stay alive. You've been warned!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
												I love to have the freedom to explore in games and that's where Miasmata delivers. It's actually the entire game. You wake up on a beach and have to roam the landscape, searching for botanical ingredients to a plague cure and piecing together the story of a group of researchers who recently occupied the area.The really great bit to the game is how a handful of minor obstacles shape the experience. Your character starts the game sick, so he's not able to run for long without getting winded, climb steep slopes, or swim more the a few feet in deep water. If you try to push him harder, he'll just get sicker. When he starts to run a fever, he needs medicine or bedrest or it gets slowly worse until he collapses. When you're not as sick, it's still very easy to get lost. There's a map, but you have to update it by triangulating your location from known landmarks. On top of all that, there's a mysterious creature on the island that occasionally harrasses you. All the obstacles are pretty easy to overcome or avoid, but when you make one mistake, it usually snowballs, culminating in a frenzied attempt to get to safety.The story is very minimal and based mostly on found notes, but it's just enough to add to the mood while letting the experience be your own. Miasmata has a very lonely beauty to it and few limits that seem artificial.  Almost the entire experience is just you stumbling through the woods, but it still manages to be compelling.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												This is definitely a game I'd recommend for people who enjoy solitary survival game experiences. As a man with the plague, you find yourself stranded on the island of Eden and must find your way in first person to concoct treatments and, eventually, the cure for your ailment. But there's more than the plague and the hazards of the island to deal with... A massive feline that is constantly on the move, and when it sniffs you out, you become its new plaything.For two men (brothers I believe) working on this game alone from scratch (even the engine is in-house), the results of their labor is astonishing. The quality of the visuals show the lack of manpower, but are still so brilliant and beautiful. The depth of mechanics present in the game is great, from map triangulation and navigation to day/night and weather cycles to swimming and sleeping to just how many ways the plague affects your character.Some of these mechanics, as one might imagine, are more cumbersome than others. It's surprisingly easy to find your character sliding downhill and then tumbling head over heels, dropping everything you held in your hands for the way back. While weapons are present (rock, knife, etc.) and can be thrown, there's ironically no way to injure or kill other creatures (eating is not a mechanic in this game, so it's somewhat forgivable). However, your character is so fragile early on in the game that this alone often determines whether you live or die should you encounter the cat in a place where you can't find shelter or hide.It's truly a shame that the cat had so much work put into it (seriously, it's the ONLY actual enemy in the game, and several blog posts from the devs talk about how much work was put into the AI for it), and yet for so many, myself included, it feels as though the game would be better off without it. The design of the creature is pretty neat, and all that goes into how it acts around you, how its presence affects your character, is amazing to me - but it feels entirely unnecessary and oftentimes serves more as a frustrating barrier to meeting your goals than an actual threat, especially when you figure out how to manipulate it. Yep, even with all of the enemy AI compiled into one creature, this beast is still easily manipulated. At least he attacks you now - which wasn't the case shortly before I bought this game. The poor thing was bugged and would just follow you around until it decided to bugger off.Still, this game is a great experience, and the storytelling is slow and delicious with the exploration for survival. It's a long one too, especially if you have no idea where to go or become forgetful like me. I have several more hours in this game than listed (a fair amount of time spent offline) and I don't think I got much more than a third of the way through the game, mostly because I got lost. Which is easy to do.Give it a try if you're into survival. It will definitely scratch that itch.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is not for everyone. It was made by two people, and it is therefore a little rough around the edges. The graphics are by no means bad, but they are certainly not AAA-quality. The two brothers who made the game designed the engine as well (which is kind of impressive), but they clearly were not able to optimize it to run as well as some better-known game engines, so you may not get quite the frame rate you expect, and you will see lab equipment pop-in when you approach a campsite. There are a few other things that are imperfect as well. All that said, THIS GAME IS AMAZING! The strange thing about this game is that I had imagined a game remarkably similar to Miasmata, but never expected it to actually exist. When I saw it on Greenlight, I was surprised that such a game finally existed. When I played it, I was quite satisfied. This is a true survival game: stand still long enough, and you will die from lack of water/fever/creature attack. Exploring the island, making your own map by triangulation, finding plants to make medicine, finding notes and journal entries that help you figure out what's going on, and hiding from that creature add up to a great survival experience. The movement system of the game is also great. It more effectively simulates illness than any other game I have seen. If you go down too steep a slope, or go down too fast, you'll slip, eventually going head over heels. You have to carefully manage your momentum by holding back while going down a slope, or examining the terrain to find a safe path down or around. This both avoids the usual video game problem of being able to run around everything in a way that would not work in real life, and the problem of walking becoming boring; your illness makes walking a game challenge. As a final note, I love the UI, more accurately, the lack of UI, in this game. Your character carries an actual journal and map that you use in real time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												I'm not a big fan of survival games but I am utterly fascinated by Miasmata. The main draw for me is that you never have a persistent map that shows your location, instead you have find your location by triangulating with known landmarks, which encourages caution in exploration and always checking your bearings. If you think you can just go running into the woods haphazardly think again because the game will punish you with one or a combination of three mechanics:The first mechanic is realistic terrain traversal and falling mechanics. Your character builds momentum as they go down gradients and you can't just stop on a dime, which is particularly dangerous if you're right next to a cliff. Falling is also realistic, as your character will take damage, drop items, and get stunned from heights that one would expect to get hurt from in real life.The second is the creature, the single enemy in the game that persistently follows you, the idea of which always keeps you on edge, I actually found it quite frightening.You can't kill it, the game purposely leaves weapons lying around to prove this point, and you can't flat out outrun it. It makes you think twice about going out at night, and you'll always keep in mind where is the nearest body of water.The third is simply getting lost. As I've mentioned before since there is no persistent map it is very easy to lose track of where you are and to just start going around in circles aimlessly in the woods. The game purposesly gives you a limited amount of inventory slots, and you'll die out quick if you don't know where you're going.Given the love the developers have put into this three game and the unique mechanics, it is well worth the $15 they're asking for.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												At first, I thought this game was awful. The graphics kinda made me seasick. I quickly tired of the novelty of the walking physics, and sliding around just became irritating. I made disparaging remarks about its clunkiness. I didn't understand really what to do, and I just kept getting hopelessly lost. But I was still playing. Over time, I realized I was thinking about this game at work and in the shower. I couldn't wait to get home and find plants and whip out my compass. I was so immersed, and I loved every second of it. By the end, I was deftly popping up to high spots to make some quick marks on my map, chugging water, doing my science, and creeping to my goal with tingling excitement. I came back around on the idea of the walking physics. I was telling friends and family about my progress in the game, even though they didn't care. I ended up gifting it to two people. For a game that I initially thought I hated, it turned out to be probably one of the best gaming experiences I've had in a long time. It's definitely worth giving this one a fair chance and overlooking some of the rough edges. My only complaint is that now I just want *more* so I have an excuse to go back to the woods.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2013
												Its overall an interesting game in which you look for plants to create medicines and eventually cure a deadly plague you have contracted. At first you will make basic medicines to temporarily treat the fever, then later you will make stat boosting medicines that will enhance your Strength, Endurance, or Perception permanently.You could also make temporary stat boosting medicines, then eventually you will find the more rare and important plants, synthesize the cure, then leave the island and sail home.It's a shame it has technical issues up the♥♥♥♥♥for me, such as blue screening sometimes if I read a document in fullscreen mode, so I have to play in windowed mode to avoid that. And worst of all, the random framerate drop that takes my framerate to around 5-10 FPS and won't go away unless I restart the game.In the end, its a game with a cool concept but actually beating the game is a little too damn complicated because the 6 plants you need to synthesize the cure is spread so far across the island I could beat 5 other games betime I find them.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												The interface is a bit clunky, but I got into this game.  There's some innovative ideas here, especially how mapping works and turning that into a realistic and believable challenge (having to use sightings to triangulate position and such). It can be frustrating with the slow movement and weakness of your character.  The map is also quite large.  But, the story--which you get mostly via notes you find--is done well and the ending is pretty cool.  I got this game for like 3 bucks on sale and at that price it's a good deal for sure.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												An excellent game of exploration and survival. The visuals and ambiance of the island are really good in helping set the mood as you find and research various medicinal qualities of the local flora to find a cure for your plague ridden character, all the constructing a map using triangulation off of landmarks, uncovering clues about the what has been going on both on island and off, and running and hiding in terror of the creature that stalks you.Rough edges are a plenty, but still a very worthwhile experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2013
												In Miasmata, the player explores an island in search of plants, to craft a cure for a disease. The game is almost entirely non combat, which may put off some gamers. You will be attacked by a creature at various times, but its best to just run away and hide. You can also be injured by falling down hills, and will die if you don't heal fast enough. Other threats include thirst, sleep deprivation and drowning. Crafting plants can restore health and provide buffs. I loved how much freedom the player is given. Miasmata is a lesson for AAA developers about how to create an open world without waypoint markers, and still guide the player to quest locations in an intelligent way. There are lots of clues to find such as maps and journal fragments, which point you in the right direction. If you're willing to overlook some minor flaws such as graphical glitches and menu presentation, this is a really nice, intelligent game, and easily worth the indie game purchase price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
												Miasmata is an open world, survival, adventure game where you must craft medicines to cure a disease that is slowing killing you.  There are other medicines that you can create to help you on your journey but beware, for the interior of the island lurks a creature that is hell bent on killing you before the plaque does.  Unfortunately, that's where many of the plants grow that can aid your condition.Pros:- Highly detailed world- Passage of time- The island is very diverse in it's topography- Mapping the island is fun (at lease for me it was)- Various plants, many with medicinal properties- Many notes and pictures to find that will give you clues to plant locations- You get to play scientist- There is no place on the island where you can't go- Numerous unique buildings, ruins, tents, dot the landscape, several with notes so you want to visit them allCons:- The game is not well optimized- It is very VERY easy to get lost if you leave the path and you will leave the path... many times- The creature seems to show up at the most inconvenient times (but then again, it's more of a pet peeve then a con)Besides fashioning medicines, one of the most entertaining activities for me was mapping the island.  I've always had a interest in cartography.  If you want to map the entire island, you have to be clever on where you stand and find two known points of reference, especially when it comes to mapping the interior.  At the time of this review, Miasmata was selling for $14.99.  Well worth it in my opinion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Miasmata is certainly a unique experience. I strongly advise going in with as little foreknowledge as possible. This review is as spoiler-free as possible.To get it out of the way: Yes, the player character is a fragile, delicate little cinnamon bun. Know why? He's deathly ill. He is literally dying of plague that's what the game's about. If you absolutely cannot handle following paths at a reasonable walking pace, if you want to be able to bound over hills and swim entire oceans, this game is not for you.If you suffer from motion sickness (as I do), you may find this game initially triggers it but that it later settles down as you get used to it. You've got two hours in which to refund if it really is too much, and those two hours should be enough time to either adjust or realise you're never going to. I found turning down mouse sensitivity drastically helped.On to the actual reviewThis game primarily focuses on exploration and discovery. There is a lot of walking. There is also a small amount of reading, chemical experimentation, swimming...and there is a threat to your life besides the plague, but it truly is best to know nothing more than that prior to playing.I loved this game's mapping mechanics. Mostly. There were occasional moments in which I hated it, frustrated that the leaves of distant trees blocked the singular visible pixel of a landmark for nineteen seconds out of twenty. However, I nontheless completed the map. Completely, bar one tiny white smudge. If I ever hear of another game with a map system similar to Miasmata, it will be a near-instant purchase for me.The game itself explains everything you need to know as you're playing it. There are story elements scattered about, but you can ignore those if you don't feel like reading. There are a few things for you, the player, to figure out, but you again you don't have to if you don't want to.Generally speaking, Miasmata can be played at any pace. Rush through it. Spend a whole year on it. There's no rush. Really.Probably.Sadly, this is what a review looks like when avoiding mentioning possibly the best thing in the entire game. But that, you must discover for yourself. If you enjoy exploration and are comfortable with a slow, clumsy avatar and a fairly mechanics-free game, you will likely enjoy Miasmata. Especially if you like surprises.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Miasmata can seem minimalistic at times, but that's what's charming about it. Since there are no zombies or machine guns, you find yourself wandering the woods or just watching the sunset on the beach with a huge stone-faced statue in the distance. Although the focus is on retreiving items, after you start piecing the map together your main motivation is to simply see what's over the next hill.Miasmata is a fun, believable survival experience well worth the minimal price.

Posted: January 12, 2013
												Miasmata truly is something a little different. The games motivation come from exploring, you keep finding little notes everywhere, which drive the story. Even though it says that you are sick and you need to develop a cure, you will never die as long you keep drinking and sleeping, and out of the creatures way, which is (mildly) stalking you. The game looks a little antiquated, but it still managed to be beautiful at times. It's a holiday on a deserted island - with copses scattered around and a evil creature hunting you - but no pressure at all. It's great fun if you are into exploration. :)

												Simple but very well implemented and a joy to play. As others have said the running away from the monster element is feeble and more of a nuisance than an excitement though the first couple of times it is frightening. The main part of the game is running round the island and trying not to get lost. It sounds simple but it really is excellent fun.There is also some gathering of plants and making medicines which is so-so, and a bit of piecing together of history by reading scraps of papers you find. It seems that more and more games use this technique and it is nearly always feeble. Fortunately it doesn't detract from the game.I think it was made by a two person team. If so, congratulations to them.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												This game was amazing; it was everything I expected it to be. It's a pretty mellow slow paced exploration game that requires patience. The island is beautiful and the weather was fantastic. The story and concept are great especially the cartography. The creature was a little scary, a little annoying, but played its part very well. I didn’t even mind the bumbling controls once I got used to them, in fact they added to the experience.I managed to play for 32 hours across 1 full playthrough, 1 speed run (achievements), and 1 playthrough for remaining achievements.I'm a little disappointed the devs abandoned the game leaving behind some achievement bugs. Nothing game breaking unless you consider getting all the achievements important like I do.Huge shout out to DarkStarSword  for his excellent work on the Unofficial Community Patch  and Miaschiev bug fixer. I couldn't have completed the game without his work.Once the game is done, there is no replay value which saddens me a lot. I want to play again but the game is exactly the same every time. I wish there was a "random" playthrough where the important flowers changed requiring you to analyze them each time to figure out their use. The flowers could also randomize locations and the maps and notes would not be present since you already know the story.10/10 Would play again if I could.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												A really nice, relaxing game. You explore and chart an island, find ingredients, craft potions with them and try not to get eaten by a mysterious creature that lives on the island. Your ultimate goal is to find the correct ingredients to create a cure for a plague that has infected humanity, including you.At first this may sound like a typical survival horror game, but it is not. You will hardly ever see the creature and if you do it's relatively easy to escape or hide. The potions you craft aren't really needed either as the creature is the only enemy in the game and all you need to stay alive is water (which you can find almost everywhere) and a bed (which is also easy to find since there are huts and tents from a previous expedition scattered across the island). So why is it fun you may ask. Simply because the island looks beautiful and is fun to explore, the cartography game mechanic is wonderfully implemented and moving your character around is fun and different as well - since he's infected with a disease he is quite hard to control (in a positive way) and if you don't pay attention he'll fall down a ledge or pass out.If you're looking for an action game or a (survival) horror game look elsewhere. If you like a relaxing game where you slowly explore an island and discover what happened to the scientific expedition that arrived there before you then Miasmata is definitely worth playing.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												While you can win this game within 5 minutes, it will probably take you about 24 hours to play.  It is cheeky like that.  If you like orienteering around an island trying to find useful stuff to help you survive and mixing drugs and going for the occasional sliding tumble to yuor death through foliage while being chased by Cat-thulhu (or was it Tabbythogua?) this game might be for you.  It is not a typical game, in that you lack the tools necessary to kill the critter, but you are on the island to save your civilization from a terrible plague, and if you are clever, you will.  I loved scurrying through the underbrush trying to find the proper vantage points to triangulate distances and map the world, it was an odd and enjoyable mechanic that I became kinda OCD about doing over and over again.  Finishing this game was strangely satisfying and I liked it, but I just know it will not be everyone's "cup of tea".

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												This is a wonderfully designed game. I love the work they've put in it and the whole exploration aspect of it of trying to find a cure and being exiled on an island.The feeling of helplessness is really present. However, they are still a few bugs that needs to be addressed/fixed before they role this out into the public. I don't know why steam only logged me for 0.2 hours on this game when I clearly spent 2 hours or more exploring everything, but here's my take on some of the negative thinks I found in the game.1.) Often times, my character would clip through rocky surfaces, house walls, trees and even fall under the map. This needs to be fixed.2.) Sometimes when you die, the character's voice would get stuck in a loop until you restart, load or exit the game.3.) Often times I would die for no reason, such as walking knee-high on water or clipping houses and structures.Apart from that, this game has been very wonderful. While I do believe and feel that this game still feels like it's in early access and should be polished up more, I will not deny that this game offers replayability and numerous content for players to enjoy. I hope the developers take the time to address these issues with an update in the future.8/10 - My honest review.

												Get this game! A totally unique style of gameplay where the common goal of survival is given an uncommon element where survival is not achieved through constant violence. Miasmata really takes the player down a notch. After playing games where you just run around exploding people with ease, you are suddenly thrown into a world where if you run into some form of predator, you're powerless! Hide! Run! If you're lucky, wave that torch! The controlls were a good attempt on how one would move in real life, but have their flaws and are a little clunky. Walking is not really an option unless you're sneaking, and I perfer not to be sprinting blind through brush (p.s. there was a cliff). So get out there! Run, hide, forage, cultivate, and above all, stay thirsty my friend.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												Miasmata is, hands down, the best exploration game I have played, and one that I consider to be among my best purchases.I have so much to comment on, but I'll try to focus on just the most pertinent points.The game world feels extremely vibrant, with beautiful scenery and memorable features. Exploration is *the* thing to do and forms the main gameplay loop - you don't have an "automap" that tells you where you are, you have to make the map by finding your location from known landmarks, then triangulate from there to pinpoint the location of unknown landmarks. You also find much flora on the island that must be returned to a lab, analyzed, and hopefully synthesized into something useful - and much of this flora is indigenous to specific biomes and cannot be found outside of them. These twin processes make every new area, every unrecognized landmark, and every new strange-looking plant an exciting new challenge to be conquered.The game is *difficult*, and exactly to the degree it should be - it's not a grind, but it's very far from a cakewalk to achieve any objective. Saving is rationed to camps, which are liberally littered throughout the terrain but are still not trivial to find if you're lost. Getting lost is, itself, extremely easy; you'll find yourself trying to find recognizable landmarks just to know where the heck you are. Walking around isn't simple, either. The game is first-person, but unlike RPGs like Elder Scrolls, you are not some mighty warrior who can leap tall cliffs. You play a deathly-ill scientist whose physical abilities are greatly diminished. Realistic falling damage poses a challenge: Tumbling off the side of a hill will disorient you, cause you to drop items you were carrying, and may bring on the symptoms of the disease, requiring medicine to be synthesized and administered before you lose the last of your strength. Swimming is likewise an arduous and perilous pursuit. These are not problems without solutions - but throughout thegame trekking across terrain is never reduced to mindless strolling. Night-time exploration is a challenging experience that should be avoided where possible.And the creature that prowls the island is truly terrifying... Fighting is not an option, running only works for so long against something that is faster than a sick person, and so hiding is the only solution - and since you need to avoid being seen, it means it's very hard to take a good look at the beast. That makes it all the more scary. The fact that running away aimlessly is a sure way of getting lost and disoriented definitely adds to the difficulty and the tension. On the bad side of things, I found the plot to be a bit detached and not very satisfying, with the murder mystery feeling a bit out of place (even though it did add tension); and I wish the interesting ruins on the island had more backstory and interesting things to find or do in them. I did find the ending satisfying, but mostly because of the challenge overcome and less due to any story resolution, which was a bit lacking.The game is not very buggy, but I did experience an occasional crash, and its lighting at night and landmark recognition were a bit quirky at times. Replayability is probably diminishing if you get to the point where you are very well familiarized with the entire island, but that should take a very long playtime; plus it's possible to try a speed-run for the achievements, which adds another degree of challenge to veteran players.I played for a very long time before I felt that I had truly conquered the island, and it was incredibly satisfying. The credits say the game was made by only two people, which I find amazing in itself. To those two I say, incredible work - I'd love to see your future endeavors.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I've enjoyed Miasmata. It took me a long time to play it, as I had the game for several years before I finished it. It was one of my "I have nothing to play... oh, wait, let's do something in this for a bit" games.Miasmata utilizes a rather interesting mechanic: a triangulation process for mapping out the island and finding your location, which makes this game stand out a lot as I have not seen anything like it elsewhere. The AI for the monster is wonderful, as it seems to show up with enough frequency and has some great pathing and bahaviors, much like a real cat. The fact that it could show up at any time, especially when you are covering lots of ground quickly, adds to the tension and creates a great atmosphere. The snippets of story through notes create a chilling mystery set on a suprisingly beautiful island. This game, if comparrisons are made, somewhat feels "slender-esque" as you are a plague victim scouring the island for plants to synthesize a cure, and medicines to keep you alive along the way. I feel like the monster shows up more as you get closer to completion of the cure and it seems to show up more in critical areas, such as places where X plant for the cure is guarenteed. My only issue with the game revolved around the controls. The movement of the character can be wonky sometimes. I feel like it does a great job of simulating the rigors of climbing with sliding and exhaustion; however, there are many times I'd want to move a foot or so forward, maybe down a 2% grade, and the guy would either overstep or just take off running. Many a cliff have I fallen from due to this "over/undersensitivity." I've found that alternating between forward and backward as you walk down any slope can greatly reduce the threat of "tripping."There are also times where you'd trip from one-foot drops, get stuck on stairs or small logs (which is terrible when you are being pursued), bump a tree the wrong way and bounce off sideways, be following a curved ledge and start sliding to the right. I just felt I, as a human being, would be able to have better control of my footing; the game makes me feel like a baby who has just learned how to walk, yet lacks basic control. Other than movement mechanics, I have greatly enjoyed the game so far. I enjoy exploration games and find that the ability to triagulate on the map adds more to the exploration reward. Miasmata has just enough tension and "horror" to attract fans of those genres and manages to stay fresh, as the map is fairly well-sized, allowing for many hours of play.
