content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												This indie survival-adventure game, in a genre that has spiked in popularity in recent times, significantly stands out.  The plot is straightforward and an example of the power of simplicity. Your boat washes up on an island shrouded in mystery, where you hope to find a cure to the disease you suffer from. You must utilize the islands vegetation to ultimately find a cure. While you are immersed in this journey playing survivalist/botanist/mycologist, you must also utilize other skills, such as cartography, especially the process of triangulation, to navigate around. Overall, If you enjoy fun adventure games that are "open world", thrilling, and suspenseful, then this is a game worth taking a look at.8.0/10 (Let's be realistic here, there are some flaws in the game....It is not perfect, by any means)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												+ Great worldbuilding that invites exploration.+ Unique triangulation system for filling in your map. Yes, this is largely about exploring unknown areas and filling in the map. It's fun to get lost and try to find the way back.+ Foraging is pretty fun. You get hints for where to find certain plants, and then hunt them down and brew different drugs from the plants.+ Pretty funny physics where you stumble and roll (and sometimes die) if you go too fast down a hill.- The game crashes every time you alt-tab, at least on my system. Because of this, I just stopped playing halfway. Who wants to restart the game every time they have to do something outside the game?- You can only carry 2 plants at once. This is really stupid considering half the game is about foraging plants.- Uninspired survival elements. Drink water and find a bed regularly. Whoop-de-doo.- The "scary" monster is just corny and annoying and feels really out of place.I'm conflicted about recommending this game but chose to make it negative because of the price. It's worth some money, but really not 14.99e. I would recommend buying it at 2e or something now that I've tried it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Very good game, but it's certainly not for everyone. Don't expect Michael Bay explosions and action.The game itself is just walking around the island, making the map yourself with triangulation, picking various plants and turning them into potions/medicine and making sure you will not die from dehydration and going too fast (yes, that is a thing). All of this while you are chased by a wierd cat/lion/panther/demon/whatever hybrid.It kind of feels like Robinson's Reqiem, but without everything trying to kill you.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Although i perhaps exaggerate now a little bit, but my personal opinion is, that Miasmata is a really astonishing masterpiece. The graphic quality almost reaches the standards of extremely expensive engines made by big companies, but is in fact made by just 2 guys. Surely it has some flaws, like the grainy looking water in the distance and no waves along the shores. The fog sometimes act a little bit strange and there are proplems like torches/sticks dont illuminate the logbook or map. But all of that is compensated by the incredible atmosphere. Starting extremely weak and as easy pray, you have to find water, plants and safe spots to survive. Creating medicine to keep you alive and to find the cure for the plague. Running around the island can be tricky sometimes, because the terrain affects your speed. It requires a lot of strenght to climb up a hill and you may stumble while running down, which causes a headache and in the worst case deadly high fever. Another great feature is, how you can create the map of the island. The easy method is to find pieces of the map around the camps. The other method is to draw a small piece of it by marking 2 known landmarks which are in sight. While exploring the island, you are watched by a creature lurking in the shadows of the Jungle, which will soon start to hunt you down. You dont have weapons and all you can do is to hide, distract the creature or run for you life. But there is one power you have, which will scare the beast away.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
Genre: Survival "Adventure" FPSReccommendation: Worth to play if you like the survival genre, as long as you are patient.Playtime: ~14 hours.Rating: 9.5/10Review:A nice, beautiful game, different from any other out there. The beginning was a little weird and dull, but once you travel more into the island, you will begin to understand how you're supposed to play and think in this game. Such moment is when you realize this is a one-of-a-kind game.The game tries to simulate realism, and although it may seem to go overboard on some parts, it does everything very well (except for nights, which are strangely pitch black even if moonlight should give a little help, so I reccommend you avoid being outside at night, but that's quite the only bad thing I see about this game).The controls might as well be weird, but that's because it tries to simulate real life even more. You're not supposed to be able to turn around 180 degrees and run straight away just like that in real life, right? Well, you can't just do that in this game either. It's not something too bad though, and it's easy to get used to it.I was surprised when I reached one of the primary objectives in a certain place of the island, where the scenery was just great, and the search for a specific rare plant, was an interesting experience like in no other game.When I encountered the "Creature" (which I like to refer to as Miasmata, even if that's a bit cheesy and the creature has no official name), that's when the game turned much more into a survival game. I was always checking my surroundings carefully and hiding from a practically invincible beast, until the moment I'd notice the creature is nearby, and that always made my heart race, even if this game isn't a horror or anything scary based game. You have to manage to not only survive your sickness, but you also have to survive being hunted down by such predator.Overral, this game is one of the greatest survival/adventure games out there in my opinion, as I really love this game and it got me addicted very soon after I began playing. Rating: 9.5/10, would have been a full 10 if it wasn't for the unfortunately frustrating pitch black nights.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I wanted this game because of the atmosphere I thought (hoped) it would create and it actually does a pretty good job in creating a lonely, lost vibe on a mysterious island. I liked that part. They also did a great job with the plant life and landscape of the island. I never felt like I was walking through the same repeated textures and wilderness. It really felt like the woods. I grew up in the woods so I have a pretty good idea of what wandering around in them feels like and they pulled this off.Here's why I ultimately didn't like this game. It just got boring. Once the scenic beauty wore off and the a lot of the statues and plants were found and a few run ins with the monster that is stalking me. I would just kind of wander around looking for something to do and the only thing to do was to look for more plants which couldn't keep my interest. They were almost there with this game but it didn't quite get it done for me in the end.

number of helpful: 16 of 31 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												The first thing I should say is I do not know a single person who completed this, or wanted to.Before you purchase this game, it isn't Myst. It is not Doom. It's not even "Dear Esther". Here is what I think it is:Picture yourself on an island where everything is made of ice. Hills you climb are so slippery, you slid to the bottom no matter what you do. Falling gives you a fever. Always. Fevers mean stopping gameplay to make a medicine. You don't eat, but you sure drink a lot of water. The object of the game is to mark all of the island giant heads  (well, you are supposed to be finding plants to cure a plague, but that's a lost cause). That's about it - no real game play, no challenges, just don't trip, don't walk through ankle deep water or you will drown.Sound fun? You are correct. It's not. I played for over 20 hours and the last 15 was just to try to complete it, hoping there was some massive reveal. There isn't. Pass on this one. It's a 3/10 at best.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												8/10. Miasmata writes the book on empathy with in-game characters. As a survivor you are alone. The outside is dangerous. The shelters are far apart and minimal. Darkness absorbs you suddenly. The night is always something to fear.Definitely, this game has its issues. There are texture bugs and clipping problems, but the navigation and map-making cartography is unique and gives an interesting take on how to get to your "point B". The creature/monster is very unique, being cat-like and behaving much as a predator would. She is colored by her surroundings and can stalk the poor survivor for miles. She becomes the thing you fear more than falling down the hills (which is quite annoying in some locations). Personally, I have taken to calling her Maxine, and navigating around the island would get me saying, "Not right now Maxine, I don't have time for this" to my monitor as soon as the heartbeat quickened. I really like this game. It took me 30 hours to complete, and I still have more achievements to do.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Very sluggish controls--you sidestep at roughly 1/5 of your forward speed.Frustrating lack of traction--you will slip off of cliffs that should have been easy to stay on, leading to a long walk back up if you don't die. Even worse, if you find a rare plant and then slip, even if you only fall a few feet, you will drop the plant, and have to go back to where it grows to get another one.Also, falling off cliffs gives you a fever for some reason, which necessetates finding medicinal plants to treat it, or a bed to sleep in, else your vision is screwed up.The map requires you to sight two known landmarks before it marks your position. Move 2 inches and reopen the map? Sorry, need to site two landmarks again, I forgot where you were standing.Interesting premise, but great number of frustrating factors lead to an unfun experience. Do not buy.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
Product received for free
												I loved the experience of exploring this landscape! They really captured the feeling of running down a hill, on the edge of control, and that's what makes exploring this world, especially when running, so fun. What keeps it fun is the scale of the environment: the ecology of the island is quite varied, depending on where you are. You're really rewarded for striking out in your own direction and exploring, and the fact that you have to manually fill in your map adds to this, making you feel like you really know the land. And getting to know the land is, of course, really helpful when you're trying to get about, especially at speed. This game may not be for the impatient, or those who need their hand held and told where to go and what to do all the time, or who like to feel in control over everything, but if it was, it wouldn't be so rewarding for the rest of us.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Pros:1. Looks very goodCons:1. The monster is completely inept.  I've encountered it several times, and usually it'll just lurk nearby and disapear.  Even when I can get it to attack me, it doesn't actually do any damage.  2. Lots of tedious walking.3. The physics is frustrating.  If you hit even a mild slope, you either go sliding thirty feet if you go downhill, or it you slowly trudge uphill.  4. Mundane things hurt you.  You can drown in two feet of water, or go sliding down an aforementioned slope, go flying into the air, and come down hard.  5. The only time I've died is when I deliberately swam out into the ocean trying to drown myself.  6. For a survival game, there isn't any surviving.  You get thirsty, but there's always an abundance of fresh water to drink.  You never have to eat or build a shelter, and the only ill effect you can suffer is a fever, which is easily taken care of by sleeping for a few hours.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2013
												Miasmata is a tough game to recommend.  It's not that the game is particularly bad or anything (I think it's a great experience honestly), but it's one of those games that is so unique that it will most likely polarize people.Miasmata is a game of survival and exploration.  You wake up on the shores of an uncharted island stricken with a plague.  Your primary goal is to cure it, and you do this by collecting plants, researching them, and discovering their properties.  This is what you'll spend most of the game doing, aside from dealing with the occasional run in with the creature that roams the isle.  The game is highly immersive.  It pulls you in with a strong sense of place.The only major issues with this game comes from the technical side.  There are lots of graphical glitches here and there (the pop in is particularly bad at some points), and the framerate occasionally dips (at least on my laptop it did).  Considering the game was designed entirely by two brothers, I can actually look past most of these issues.If you want a gaming experience like nothing you've played before, I would highly recommend this game.  If you are not the patient type, I would caution you on this one.  This is definitely a game that rewards patient exploration, and if that's your thing, then you are in for a treat.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												"It was time to get out of Eden. I took off at full sprint across the length of my dominion. Joy and remorse swashed around my mind like two components of one of my synthesizing drugs. Despite all the pain this island represented,  it also represented hope and resilience. But ultimately, I felt joy that I would soon be freed from this prison.As I ran past my familiar haunts, I was confronted with the sins of my scientist brethren: their bodies litter the island and rot in one accord. I felt complicit in the same cold-transgressions of power-pursuit and going to any length possible to survive, but I can’t help but feel like a changed man.At the end of my final run through the island, I saw my escape. And I swam for it. But as I swam, I didn’t mind looking back. Almost afraid I’d be turned to stone like Lot’s wife, I couldn’t help but miss this terrible place.Do I miss the fight for survival, the desperate quest for a cure, and the haunting notion that everybody else on the island is dead? I really do. Now, I sit here. I’ve made my final triangulation. But I don’t need to. I already know where I am. I’m on my way home."Read more: http://gamechurch.com/three-weeks-in-eden-a-chronicle-of-human-strength-and-weakness-in-miasmata/

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												The creature adds a very small horror element of the game, but this is not a "survival horror" game. The emphasis is almost exclusively on survival and the sense of adventure (traveling to a new place and discovering new things). As someone who cares deeply about science and discovery, this game was very refreshing and engaging for me, despite its nagging technical and design issues.I highly recommend that anyone with a similar passion for science, discovery, and adventure give Miasmata a try. It is very rough around the edges, but its dedication to its novel niche concept makes it worthwhile. It's a game that is geared towards a specific audience, and that audience will likely love the game. For anyone else, it could be a passable diversion, but you might find it too dull and boring to play to completion.Full review on my personal blog: http://www.megabearsfan.net/post/2015/01/03/Miasmata-game-review.aspx

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												Pro:The map system is great, in fact it is the only thing worthwhile in the game.  While it could utilize a lot of work (including creating your own marker points) it is the first semi-realistic mapping system I have seen.  Cons:Bad Physics with a fair try.  they tried to make the system quasi physics based (but took physics 101 and stupped), the speeds and slowdowns are unrealistic and remind me of mario on ice or something that way.  Your like some old weak freak that can't climb worth crap or fall more than 3 inches, gets tired after a short (very short) sprint, and falls like a drunk on saturday night.  Moving is frustrating and pathetic.You can only carry one object, 3 flowers, and apparently a book with you.  While many games let you carry more than is realistic, this game thinks the only place to hold things is your hand apparently.  Oh and don't go for a swim, you will drop everything (and likely never find it again), even a tiny pond can mess you up.Graphics Suck:  There is no brightness control, so at night on my screen is pitch black, a cloud makes it as dark as night would be.  Due to the poor graphics (I maxed them out and still the detail is crap) you can see things very far away with in detail, as the game's mapping system requires you notice things far away, this is a pain.Boring:  Outside of mapping and needing to drink 5 galons of water a day, the only thing you do is gather plants in an attempt to find the right mixes.  There is a beast on the island to chase you around, though I am not exactly sure why.  You can only carry three flowers on you, so to do any real experimenting requires you do a lot of back and forth.  No need to protect yourself from weather or even eat food, so it does not even qualify as a survival game.Suggestions:Take the mapping system, get rid of the monsters, and be the first true survival game.  So many games out there come close on a lot of areas, but mess it up by either adding unbeatable uber monsters or have crappy world interactions.  This game does both. The idea of a quest/story line is great, but it's so tedious and slow to get flowers, the I feel it falls very short of it's potential benefit.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												A great horror-survival-exploration game that's worthy of attention.You begin the game stranded on a beach, exiled because of a contagious disease...That's it, then it's basically up to you to explore, find clues and try to stay alive in hope of finding a cure.Quick Summary:This game is a great example of an exploration game where you need to make sure you have enough waterto stay alive and where, at night, losing your source of light is the worst thing ever,while avoiding an unknown creature and trying to find a cure for your condition bysearching the local plantlife for ingredients.It is an immersive, tense and beautiful experience that I highly recomment to everyone interested.+    Atmosphere:        Man does this game nail everything I like about atmosphere and ambiance.        It is stunning and mysterious at day and yet absolutley terrifying and pitch-black at night,        and the ambient sounds really makes the environment come alive.    Sound:        While the game has almost no music, it more than makes up for it by the afromented ambient sounds        which range from flowing water to tweeting birds.+-    Graphics:        Alright, let's face it: the character model looks kinda bad, as does a few other things;        the water from the pitcher comes to mind...        The fauna however looks absolutley stunning, and you could (and probably will) get lost in the islands locales        whether merely trying to get a better view or to find new plants to experiment on.    Gameplay:        Gameplay isn't exactly what you would call exiting and is a matter of taste.        Do you like picking up random plant life, checking them for new components, combining medicine,        triangulating your position trying to explore the island while keeping yourself from dehydrating or getting        sick-er as well as being scared because darkness is falling then getting lost for days on end?        Also, there is a creature on the island that is far from friendly...        Personally, I love it, it is a tense experience, but it might not be everyone's cup of tea, but on the other        hand, if any or all of these sound appealing to you I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												In light of recent epiphanies I have had regarding my dislike of this game I have come up with a new, conciser review, but will keep the old one for... posterity or whatever.New Version:This game is a pioneer of the genre of early-access survival games, from before early-access even existed. Games like these feature a few neat gimmicks, a loosely established goal, and a veneer of realism, but are plagued by bugs and shoddy mechanics that are doomed to never be fixed. Today these games sit in the early-access section getting trivial updates every month or so until suddenly the developers get bored or realize that nobody is buying their game anymore and they give up. The game is left unfinished and forgotten.Miasmata gives the impression of being one of these forgotten end-products, except someone accidentally gave it a full release.Old Version:I was mildly enjoying this game until I accidentally strayed from the exact path the game wanted me to follow and I became hopelessly lost, unable to chart anything on my map, because obviously you can't map anything without a reference that is already on your map! You can't like start a new map and combine it with your old one later or something! That would be silly!Other assorted problems:The flame of the lighter has a faint green square around it where transparency is supposed to be.Trees produce an unnatural aura of darkness.Night is pitch black and if you aren't near a bed you basically have to stand around for 15 minutes until the sun rises.Falling over gives you a debilitating illness. (SO REALISTIC)Your character seems to think slopes are about twice as steep as they actually are.The monster is really dumb and it's hard to tell if you can even interact with it because its behavior makes no sense.I think there's some other glitchy stuff but I don't remember. I last played this game like over a year ago.Good things:The interface with the journal and the water bottle and medicine and stuff is pretty cool.Collecting flowers and mushrooms and making stuff is pretty cool I guess.The concept of the map making is pretty cool.That's about it.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												With the first trailer i was hooked for a survival sim, but while i played the game it become fast a big disappointment.The game has 3 main game mechanics: discovering ( with a unique trainqulation/map system and a bit story telling), creating medicine ( thought finding, anaylsing and mixing the ingredients) and surviving (care the fever with medicine and water, avoiding monsters, sleeping at night and use fire/light to enlight or defense)I like the idea to discover new plants and research the right medicine for your fever/plague and the variety is big, but it´s getting fast boring.My biggest problem is the broken and clumys player momvent. It take so long to climb a flat hill and you rush so fast down hill. Turning around and move left/right/back is slowly and is disproportionate sluggish by contrast with straight foreward. This sounds like a no big deal, but it´s so fundamental to this kind of game and it´s broken and frustrated me fast :( I wish they  take more time to the balancing and make some testing. It´s seems pretty unpolished.It feels so un-sastisfaying to discover or travel around the map with this problems. Also there are many other bugs like sound cliping errors, menu glitches, texture rendering bug and many more.Even on the hightes graphic settings it looks like and feels like a game from 2005.I know it´s hard to make a good game with two persons with such big world (ambition), but its even leaking the basics of game design, so I can´t recommend this game :(All the best for the next project!

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												This is one of those unpolished "games" that takes minimalism - and itself - too seriously. Ultimately, it's the little things that make this game unenjoyable.1. "What the heck am I seeing?"When you shave off so much of the UI as to be non-existant, you defeat the purpose. There is almost no in-game text to help discern what you are looking at. I am not a botanist, so don't expect me to instantly categorize and identify each plant the game presents. Since textures are recycled so much, it is impossible to discern or orient yourself (see gripe #3).2. "What the heck am I hearing?"Put simply, the sound is atrocious. It lacks true ambience, and the music only comes up in the menu. Most annoying is the fact that the same bass effect is used for being preyed upon by predators AND the sound of your heart when you strain yourself, so after one too many encounters you cannot tell if your character is just paranoid or stupid.3. "Where the heck am I?"Getting lost sucks. It isn't fun to try to figure out where you are. Coming back to the game later means having almost no idea where anything is anymore. You get a map, but you have to fill it in manually by way of triangulation... except that the surroundings are so thick that you cannot view almost any landmark - and no, you cannot look through the foliage. The fact that you are under pressure of a disease means meandering about aimlessly is not an option... which takes us to gripe number 4.4. You can only carry one of anything.I spent hours of game time harvesting ingredients and making multiple doses of key medicines, only to find later that I only had one dose in my inventory. The game never tells you that your giant pillbox can hold only a single dose of anything. I get easily fifty mints in an Altoid tin, so don't tell me this is even close to the realism they otherwise try to evoke.5. Immersion is great, until it becomes boring.Walking simulators have to strike a fine balance between distance and speed, and this game strikes out on this concept. After the third time getting exhausted for having to sprint, it gets annoying. The environments aren't so spectacular that I can enjoy these woods. Firewatch got it much better. Look, I get that the character is supposed to be some weakling geek, but asthma sucks enough in real life without needing to bring it into a game. What next, "chemo sim 1995, where you get to watch your body rot!" - no thanks.6. Slopes and momentum are not your friend.More to the point, you have all the control of a drunkard. Walking along a slight bank, only to have the angle shift juuuust enough so that the game decides you get to take a tumble downhill is just aggravating. 7. Tools get lost with a sneeze, but plant samples? Deathgrip!The game tries so hard to be realistic but the fact that if you swim or fall then you are forced to drop weapons, yet your samples remain grasped firmly in hand is contradictory. Annoying design choices are blatant for being sophomorish. 8. Food is unnecessary, apparently!Exertion, exhaustion, strain, thirst, carrying capacity... all of these are carefully tracked in the game. Survival should incorporate food/hunger. Maybe I never got that far in the game, but after 4 days in the game world, you would expect some grumblies in the tumblies. Rabbit is tasty!9. Critters. Critters everywhere, and more silent than ninjas!Add them to the ambience, or let us kill them for food. The fuzzy animals should make fine eats, but the varmints and vermin are purely atmospheric. 10. Useless samples are uselessLiterally, why bother at all? I get it, some of them don't make medicines. However the fact that this botanist can't turn them into deterrents for predators is ludicrous. Since the UI is so minimal, there is literally no way to drop the useless stuff. Worst of all, using them in crafting wastes the useful materials - you have to figure that out, however, the hard way.11. You cannot escape the menuThis seems like a minor gripe, but it is like I said at the start that the little things add up. Having to click out of the menu that you can only access by way of the ESC key is just another example of how the developer fails to understand basic concepts of UX.TL;DR: This game is just bad. Play it if you enjoy role-playing a suffering, dying, asthmatic dweeb with zero survival skills and no preservation instinct.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												As the only person in my friends list to have purchased this game, I feel its only fair to leave a review,Miasmata is essentially a realistic survival horror (minus the need for food)Your goal is to find various plants and combine them to make a medicine that will cure you of your disease, its sort of like a more complex form of slenderTo my knowledge, there are no monsters, no people, no ghosts or anything supernatural, just wild animals and one in particular that wants to kill you. Miasmata does not go out of its way to scare you, but I feel this works more in its favor then against it. The fear comes from concepts that are very real and very obvious, you can die in the wilderness, or get lost.there are scraps of a map scattered throughout the game, but there is no pointer that shows where on the map you are, so i suggest relying on bodies of water and your compass to tell you where you are and which way you need to go.TL;DRmore of an amnesia style of horror, except with no monsters and its in the wild, is it worth 15 dollars? Probably not, but they do seem like they put a lot of work and originality behind it, so i'd suggest either wait for a sale or pay them the full 15 to show your support.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Greetings, comrades! I bought this game quite a while ago, and I really wanted to love this game. However I found it impossible to do so, which is a shame. Alright, let's go!Pros:Beautiful environment, simply brilliant graphics, with the weather patterns, day/night cycle, and the flora and fauna all fully realized and vibrant. Honestly, this game would be worth sale price simply for the graphics if you appreciate games like that.The mapping system is unique and realistic, but not TOO real as to render it not fun. In other words, it's as real as a game can make it while still being a game. I really enjoyed walking around just mapping the island. Definitely this is the game's strongest point.Cons:While the environment is well done, the detail on the hands and arms of the player are absolutely ATROCIOUS! Bad enough that, to this day, I use the term "Miasmata hands" to reflect a poorly designed first-person model. They could have at least used the standard cop-out of putting a watch or bracelet on the player's wrist to at least ease the pain of having to look at 2 ham shanks on the end of bologna rolls.The plot. Spoiler alert, your character is ill, and you must find a cure. I believe this to be an unnecessary handicap in the early game, and I personally found it insurmountable due to the rather boring nature of the quest. Also, you can't do too much in the way of travelling or running around until you found the cure.The "creature" is just a joke. I will say no more, just take my word for it.The controls are some of the worst I've ever seen. When you move the mouse, there's a delay in the motion, and when you stop, the camera "shakes" and your hands lapse over where you stopped the movement. It's really hard to describe, almost like it takes time to gain and lose momentum when looking. The same thing happens when you walk or run, which can be the death of you if you're near an edge you didn't see. Also, this same delay is present in everything you do, which is really annoying.I wish this game were better, as the concept could have been great. I just can't give this game a positive review due to all its faults.Thanks for reading, and have an awesome day!

content:
Posted: May 21, 2013
												This is a bad game, don't buy it.Your character controls like a drunk, stumbling all over the place and incapable of ascending a gentle slope at faster than crawling pace.  The game crashes when leaving the ESC menu.  There are a ton of cases where the wrong models are used during plant analysis.  The achievements are glitched to hell.You are in more danger of dying from tumbling down perfectly climbable inclines than you are of getting killed by the 'creature'.  Speaking of the creature, I met it once after playing for a couple hours.  You get a warning that it's nearby via a loud heartbeat.  There's no indication of what direction it's in, and if you see it out of cover it will see you.  However it doesn't really move very fast so if you just run away you're fine.  Despite what the store page says, it doesn't really track you- it just randomly spawns near you.  So, just run in practically any direction and you're fine until it randomly spawns near you again.  Pointless.  Oh and if it hits you, you die instantly.The landmark system sounds clever except for the fact that trees and inclines seem to be placed specifically so that you can't see landmarks most of the time.  Also there seem to be no sanity checks involved.  You can walk like 10 feet for a second triangulation to verify where distant landmarks are, and can use landmarks that are in line with you to verify your own position.  There's no minimum angle between landmarks or minimum distance between triangulations.Health is represented solely by how sick you are.  So, falling down a cliff gives you a fever, rather than bruises.  There's food on the island but you can't eat any of it because it's all half-rotten fruit.  You can supposedly drink from any non-saltwater source, but I already found a river that I couldn't drink from.This game is a MESS.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
A Paladin’s Updated Review: Miasmata. Don’t Bother Stalking This Ugly Beast.Genre: First Person Survival/Adventure Open Worldish Title.Developed & Published by: IonFXPlatform: Windows only.Business Model: Single PurchaseCopy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsYou play as Robert Hughes, a scientist who has come to an island named Eden (subtle) to cure an unnamed plague that he’s been stricken by. He hopes to meet up with a group of scientists to to work on figuring out the cure but upon arrival, he finds one of them dead and clearly something has gone wrong. What suggests to be a murder though quickly fades into the background. If there was a murderer(s) on the island, the game almost seems to forget about it after the opening ten minutes of the game. Instead, it decides to focus its attention on the crafting system and surviving the creature prowling the island to eventually fixing the cure. What little story that’s there isn’t really enough to capture my attention. Not when we’re talking about unknown persons on an unknown island trying to cure an unknown plague for themselves and an unknown number of people. If there is more lore to this game, it takes far too long to get there. What you’re left with is “surviving” the island.Gameplay ExaminationThe game features a creature that they claim will stalk you for miles, lurking behind grasses, vegetation and overall trying to hunt you down. It’s supposed to be a smart AI but it isn’t. The AI doesn’t do a very good job of hunting the player down and can easily lose sight of the player behind a thin tree. Simply outrunning it is also a viable option which really dampens the threat it has. One particular event in the game really showed me how poorly designed the AI had been. I had been heading towards a new part of the island to find more ingredients for the cure. I was walking along, seeing birds fly about when I started hearing my character’s heartbeat. So, I found some grass to hide in and crouched down. The game’s UI will warn you when the creature has spotted you. Which is interesting considering how much the devs tried to go out of their way to avoid using traditional UI before this point. There is only a limited amount of UI used, instead the game relies on in-game items like a paper map and journal to display information. It carries all of your notes, information you research and current status. It’s a pretty neat, if clunky, and in need of further polish.So, I waited for the creature to pass me by. After it did, I moved further into the island towards another outpost. Along the way there, I found a pond and I heard my character’s heartbeat going faster. The creature had found me. So, I move down the ledge, hid behind a thin tree and crouch to find out where it was. It was up on the ledge, looking for me. It then came down the ledge, awkward animations and all, going right past me. It should have spotted me at that point but apparently this super hunter is incredibly bad at hunting. It goes down to the water and circles about, unaware of where I am so I decide to test how good its “vision” is. It finally does spot me, when I had gotten far closer than I should have been able to, so I try to back off. It wasn’t having any of that so I stood my ground and decided to fight. The creature swipes a paw at me and…..nothing happens. I’m moving around a little bit but I should have been easily hit. It swipes a couple more times and still nothing happens. I decide to run away. Despite the creature following me, I suffer no damage and am able to run away. Then it gets stuck on a wall that I went around and stood there impotently growling at me. I stood there, sorely disappointed.PC Settings and Audio/VideoThe performance of Miasmata is pretty poor and older hardware will have a tough time running it. As stated before, the visuals for this game are ugly, poorly defined and lacking color. Miasmata has aged very badly in the years since I first played it. The graphics and overall style just feels ugly. I’m not even sure why it got or continues to get praise for its graphical fidelity when games that came out a year prior look far and away better than it does. Nothing is really appealing, with a world darkened by grey hues and lack of color outside of grass and the occasional flower. It’s a game that’s just draining on the eyes, if the mechanics aren’t draining on the player. There are very rare moments when the game might look good but these are outweighed by a world that needed a lot more development time. To at least make an island that would be genuinely more interesting to explore. As it stands, there’s just a lot of grass, trees, streams, beaches some flowers and small hills to run around. Nothing really peaks my curiosity about the place. Audio design is in bad need of an overhaul. While the soundtrack is reasonable, the audio atmosphere is lacking most of the time and there are plenty of sound effects missing.Final ThoughtsIt’s a very two dimensional exploration and survival game. There’s no real incentive for exploring the island. The only items that can be found are barely usable weapons, torches and flowers. That’s it. There’s no reason to explore the island for its graphics, that’s for certain.Few games have ever shattered my immersion so completely like Miasmata has done in this genre. Upon seeing the creature’s easily gameable flaws and generally being worn down by the uninteresting mechanics, I had enough. This game is just ugly, both mechanically and visually. The crafting system is a bore, the triangulation navigation system is repetitive and unrewarding and just traveling around the island can be the biggest threat to your survival, not the creature. The visual style has a sense of being constantly dirty and faded out that it drains me to even look at it. This is a game that had such promise but ultimately falls short. A custom engine that didn’t do anything that unique at the time, a premise that in the right hands could be a lot of fun but was clearly not in those hands. It didn’t help that it got very little post-release support but I guess that’s unsurprising in this case. IonFX has been very quiet since Miasmata was released to the point that I think the company may have failed. Simply put, a lot better games have come out since Miasmata and are worth your attention more than this one. Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
Meh.Poor balancing on how quickly you get tired; an inconvenient at best, tiresome and erratic at worst, system for discovering your map, and a myriad of mediocre survival indie tropes - an unimpressively simple-yet-time-consuming-to-get-ingredients crafting system.But none of those things compare to the physics engine. Oh god the physics engine. It's like you get a zany supervillan with overly elaborate gravity ray that randomly shoots the player, sending them into a mild tumble. This is your main obstacle. It makes sense if this were to trigger for you deciding to randomly jump off a cliff, but it does it a lot on the tiniest of mounds and steps.The bottom line is, it's just not fun. At all. I'm embarrassed how many hours I've racked up on it, but I guess I thought I would try get my money's worth or something. Don't try that. Your time is worth more than that.I have reasonable small-time studio expectations on what graphics are capable of being produced. But... visually everything is just a little too clunky, obtuse and unrefined to keep the atmosphere going. It's just short of bridging the gap. A strong point however is how diverse the island is, a respectable effort into the island's design is definitely there.  tl;dr: There are so many other games that do every feature you find here much better, and aren't necessarily expensive. The Forest is one that comes to mind. Maybe give it a shot if you're a die hard. There are worse games out there.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I really liked this game.I didn't at first, I wanted to as soon as I saw it but when I started playing there were things that I really didn't like about it. The controls felt clunky and it bugged the hell out of me that you could only carry a couple of things at once.But then the uniqueness of the whole experience starts to rub off on you, it's got this mapping system that makes you triangulate yourself based on landmarks you've seen when you knew where you were already.. if that makes any sense. It's good, it's not like anything I've seen in another game.I honestly spent a large amount of time in this game quite lost in random places. Because your characters sick and it's also a survival horror game, being completely lost is stressful but it adds to the experience.I'd very much recommend this game if the idea of playing an exploration based game appeals to you, the survival horror aspects aren't jump scares but more this constant feeling of paranoia / stress that accompanies exploring anywhere you've not been before.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Do you enjoy running around doing nothing for hours on end with the coordination of a 3 year old? Then this game may be just right for you!  Simply put, this game is incredibly boring.  It's a neat idea, but the execution and sheer lack of anything to do just makes it mind numbling awful to play.  You play as a scientist trying to find a cure for a disease you have by experimenting with various plants throughout the island you're trapped on.  So literally the entire game is running around a giant island looking for plants, coming back to a lab to test then, rinse and repeat until you get your cure.  Honestly it wouldn't be too bad if the game mechanics worked ok, but as said in my opening line you have about as much coordination as a mentally handicapped racoon.  Combine that with such other wonders as drowning in 3 inches of water, and you get a game who's soul aspect is exploration with incredibly aggravating controls to perform said exploration.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
tl;drNeat ideas very poorly executed.  2/10Ps & Cs+ Neat concept -- become a scientist and make your own cure+ Neat use of map -- use the environment to triangulate your location- Looks downright terrible- Stopping is like wearing skates- Always sick, always tired, always thirsty- You may carry one  item -- "hmmm, this banana or this knife..."Nitty GrittyI wanted to like this game and it seems like a cool idea just terribly executed.  In the 30 minutes I played inventory became an issue 30 times.  You may carry exactly 1 item, and if you're going to swim, you'll just drop the item at the bottom of the lake.  A torch!  Better chuck my knife on the ground to use it!  A banana!  Better chuck that torch on the ground to use it!  You have to cure your fever every day, that means you have to make medicine, which is fine.  However as you can only carry one flower, you have to pick it, create the pills, take them, and then run back to the bush to get a single flower for tomorrow and make more pills.  I think with some kind of an inventory system this game could have been decent, as it is now it is 0% fun.  I picked it up on sale for $2.99 and quite frankly would have been furious had I paid full price.  2/10

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Okay, I haven't played much of the game yet, but this is what I think and why I won't finish the game.Story aside the game seems to aim to be realistic. You can pick up rocks and throw them, you can pick up wood and make a torch, you have to drink regularly, you need to triangulate your location on a map instead of having a pointer that shows you exactly where you are at anytime etc. Yet this makes the game feel even weirder in other parts. The character moves is pretty unrealistic, you cannot swim (maybe you can train it), the triangulation works perfectly (if you figured out how) without any kind of equipment to measure distances or calculate or anything. The research is ridiculous, you grab a flower go to a shack with a microscope (and they are miraculously all over the island) cut it up, put it under the microscope and suddenly you know exactly that this thing is very effective in curing fever...if only real life science would be that easy.To top things off the inventory is amazing, not that you could carry infinite amounty of stuff, no...you can carry everything that fits in your hand...and only one hand at a time.It is cruel to the devs, but this game is for me nothing more than a redoing of the Slender Man game with more stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥in it.Edit:After playing it some more I stand with my previous review.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												Looking for an exciting game?Look somewhere else.What I was looking for I was looking for a survival based game, you know, hunt for food. Build shelter, try survive against the elements while your batteling this terrible disease. Try fight off creatures in the woods like Wolves, Bears, whatever... However, what I got was something much more boring and plain.What I gotHere is the jist of the game. You start out, dying, you have to go find plants and fungai to research to make medicine to cure your disease. Thats it!You wander around, finding plants. Your guy has to drink water to stay hydrated, also the controls are very clunky and blocky. Like walking on ice. Your guys slips and falls down small inclines all the time for no apparent reasons and there isn't much of stopping him. I see what they were attempting to do with the game. I like the idea, But it just feels very, unfinished and leaves the player wondering what there is to come. Your waiting for excitement and it never shows up. To put it plain, there is nothing about this game that will keep players coming back to it. It's not even a one hit wonder. It falls into a category that has stiff competition right now and there really is no apparent reason to play this game cause they got so many competitors that sell this genre to you and do it 100x better.Apparently there is also a creature that can attack you as well... Well. I have not seen him yet. The only thing to make you worried is this disease, but it's okay. There are plenty of plants to pick and thankfully many other games as well.

												Miasmata is a first-person survival/adventure game, developed from the ground-up by brothers Joe and Bob Johnson. You play as Robert Hughes, a plague-stricken scientist on a journey to discover a cure. Your adventure begins on the shores of a remote and mysterious island.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												Absolutely mesmerizing mixture of exploration, investigation and survival experience, which could easily shift from pure contemplation to the moments of unbearable tension. But at the same time, unlike many other survival based games, Miasmata asks you to carefully navigate and study its world, rather than conquer it with weapons and technology. So you always have to treat your environment with care and respect... just like in real life.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												I really enjoyed this game, which is saying alot, cause i really don't like horror games. The first long while is survival and exploration, and the closer you get to finding the cure, the monster appears more and more often, transitioning into a constant, look-over-your-shoulder horror. The monster itself isn't very scary...but when you can't defend yourself against it at all and you're so close to finding a new drug, that's scary on its own.Every new plant I found and researched was like a small achievement deserving a jump for joy, whether it was a simple antibiotic, a temporary boost to my stats, a part of a permanent change to my stats, or one of the key plants needed for the ultimate cure. NEVER have I been more excited about flora!What's bad about it is that there are alot of slippery slopes...literally. Due to the fact that you're traversing this seemingly empty island by foot with a increasingly degrading disease, a small slip could send you tumbling down a small hill, making your sickness worse and on top of dropping all flora you were currently holding. Though they can be found around the area of the fall, if night is quickly approaching, the creature is on the hunt, or whatever reason, chances are you'll have to trek back and pick more up, you clutz. Also, the view of the island is breathtaking, but the characters graphics, which consist of two arms, are glitchy and underdeveloped. You'll see what i mean when you see it.Start the game and you quickly realized that you are undeniably SCREWED. Finish the game, and feel like a champion for rising above such an imposing challenge.Worth buying? Yes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Miasmata has received some nice accolades but also some dissing about its graphics quality, performance and playing style. All criticisms are soft in the head and wide of the mark. There is no other game in existence that has such a complete, intuitive, rich and diverse simulation of nature in the wild. Immense care has gone into creating an edenic island with enchanting wildlife, from beetles, butterflies and frogs through squirrels to fluctuating weather conditions, wild storms and captivating sunsets. It is awesome and perfect by comparison with any other game on the market as of 4th Jan 2014. Some people have found the unrestricted wilderness exploration and cartography irritating or the beast too hard to handle. They collect a couple of plants and seem to get frustrated or bored. Others complain the sea which looks sumptuous as of Dec 2013 is lousy and unprofessional. This leaves me shaking my head in wonder. It's as if these people have become so used to a synthetic gamer's world where conflict is handed to you on a platter in spoon-fed form that when you come upon a game presenting a real life situation with actual bush crashing and navigation skills, even provided with countless prominent features such as the fire pillars and Easter Island heads on every high hill, you can't handle it. Wake up you pathetic dudes you are selling yourselves down the river, not the eden of Miasmata!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												For a game by just two developers Miasmata is really impressive. It's quite atmospheric, with the lighting and water effects in particular setting the tone, and the sound effects and music are solid.  It feels good to have no HUD and to be flicking through your journals for info instead of menus and holding up your compass instead of following a quest marker. What really sets this game apart is your character's fragility; you can't edge around and up steep hills like in Elder Scrolls games and such, and charging downhill will just cause you to trip and fall. It's a slow-paced game that mostly involves running from place to place, gathering ingredients and charting the island.However, it's all very rough around the edges. The graphics, particularly the textures, are very dated in places. The inventory system (your left hand) is slow, limited and frustrating. Don't expect combat- you can swing a knife around but it won't achieve anything other than looking bad. Ultimately, Miasmata still feels like a demo for a real game, or a sample project, but it's a very promising one. I'd love to see more from these guys- maybe not a polished Miasmata, but a similar adventure game with much higher production values.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is an interesting survival/adventure game.  Exploring the island was kind of neat.  Trying to find all the landmarks and get the entire map to show up is a bit of a challenge on its own.  There's a few buildings scattered around that you'll run into here and there that also have notes in them to give you an idea of what happened since you're all alone and don't have any idea what you're doing there.  I also liked collecting the various plants to craft painkillers and other drugs.  It almost made me wish there were more things to collect and craft than there are.My biggest complaint is a possible small spoiler, so I'll hide that next.  I found it kind of tedious once the creature starts showing up.  I was initially kind of excited the first time I saw it.  I tried to hide, but that didn't work out so well since it seemed to home in straight on me.  Pretty much when it first appears, it's not so bad since it only shows up once in a great while, but when you start progressing on your "main quest" it shows up more often.  By the time you're nearly finished with the quest, it's virtually impossible to avoid the thing.  I also had what I'd call worse than 50/50 success in hiding from it too even when I was in a spot that I was completely hidden from it at all times and not making any noise.  I even had a few times that I jammed myself between a tree and the side of a cliff that was completely hidden by leaves and grass and it still kept trying to walk straight at me even though we couldn't see each other (I know where it was walking since I had the skill that tracks the creature when you don't move).  The next small thing is when night falls and you don't have a light source, you're pretty much screwed.  It's completely black and you mostly end up literally rolling down hills on your face and/or falling into the water where you're likely to drown.  You learn real quick not to try going out at night without a torch in hand and another one nearby to take its place.Overall I found this to be an enjoyable game in spite of the complaints I have above.  It's worth a play through if you like exploring the unknown.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Miasmata is a game that redefines what you might picture as a game. It's almost not a game, in some ways; the punishing sicknesses you can get wandering around the island, the analysis of different flora to cure the aforementioned afflictions, and the use of your surroundings and triangulation to determine your position on the map...all of these things are something a person would do in the given circumstances. As a huge fan of first person games, I really enjoy the fact that the arms and hands are put to realistic use as well, and how immersive and well thought out the environment is. It surprises me still to imagine two people working on something of this scope. It has its little quirks, and some of the kinks in the fabric haven't quite been worked out just yet, but if you're looking for something that isn't your run of the mill first person shooter or puzzler, this game is definitely worth checking out.

Don't expect combat- you can swing a knife around but it won't achieve anything other than looking bad. Ultimately, Miasmata still feels like a demo for a real game, or a sample project, but it's a very promising one. I'd love to see more from these guys- maybe not a polished Miasmata, but a similar adventure game with much higher production values.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is an interesting survival/adventure game.  Exploring the island was kind of neat.  Trying to find all the landmarks and get the entire map to show up is a bit of a challenge on its own.  There's a few buildings scattered around that you'll run into here and there that also have notes in them to give you an idea of what happened since you're all alone and don't have any idea what you're doing there.  I also liked collecting the various plants to craft painkillers and other drugs.  It almost made me wish there were more things to collect and craft than there are.My biggest complaint is a possible small spoiler, so I'll hide that next.  I found it kind of tedious once the creature starts showing up.  I was initially kind of excited the first time I saw it.  I tried to hide, but that didn't work out so well since it seemed to home in straight on me.  Pretty much when it first appears, it's not so bad since it only shows up once in a great while, but when you start progressing on your "main quest" it shows up more often.  By the time you're nearly finished with the quest, it's virtually impossible to avoid the thing.  I also had what I'd call worse than 50/50 success in hiding from it too even when I was in a spot that I was completely hidden from it at all times and not making any noise.  I even had a few times that I jammed myself between a tree and the side of a cliff that was completely hidden by leaves and grass and it still kept trying to walk straight at me even though we couldn't see each other (I know where it was walking since I had the skill that tracks the creature when you don't move).  The next small thing is when night falls and you don't have a light source, you're pretty much screwed.  It's completely black and you mostly end up literally rolling down hills on your face and/or falling into the water where you're likely to drown.  You learn real quick not to try going out at night without a torch in hand and another one nearby to take its place.Overall I found this to be an enjoyable game in spite of the complaints I have above.  It's worth a play through if you like exploring the unknown.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												I really enjoyed this game, which is saying alot, cause i really don't like horror games. The first long while is survival and exploration, and the closer you get to finding the cure, the monster appears more and more often, transitioning into a constant, look-over-your-shoulder horror. The monster itself isn't very scary...but when you can't defend yourself against it at all and you're so close to finding a new drug, that's scary on its own.Every new plant I found and researched was like a small achievement deserving a jump for joy, whether it was a simple antibiotic, a temporary boost to my stats, a part of a permanent change to my stats, or one of the key plants needed for the ultimate cure. NEVER have I been more excited about flora!What's bad about it is that there are alot of slippery slopes...literally. Due to the fact that you're traversing this seemingly empty island by foot with a increasingly degrading disease, a small slip could send you tumbling down a small hill, making your sickness worse and on top of dropping all flora you were currently holding. Though they can be found around the area of the fall, if night is quickly approaching, the creature is on the hunt, or whatever reason, chances are you'll have to trek back and pick more up, you clutz. Also, the view of the island is breathtaking, but the characters graphics, which consist of two arms, are glitchy and underdeveloped. You'll see what i mean when you see it.Start the game and you quickly realized that you are undeniably SCREWED. Finish the game, and feel like a champion for rising above such an imposing challenge.Worth buying? Yes.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Miasmata excels in creating a haunting atmosphere that is at once peaceful and tense.  I enjoyed exploring the island and learning the unique cartography system while keeping one ear out for the quickening heartbeat that signalled the creature's presence.  The paranoia of the creature's sudden and inevitable appearance kept me moving from save point to save point obsessively for fear I'd lose any progress I'd made in acquiring plant samples or additions to my map.  Overall Miasmata is an interesting mystery to solve with unforgiving physics (don't try to slide down the side of a cliff for a shortcut!) set against a beautiful yet dangerous backdrop.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												I havn't made any progress at all and I've never played a better exploration game. Miasmata gives some of the most intense immersive gameplay. It requires a really good amount of patience, you can't just jump in and want to kill everything you see, even at the start it puts you in somewhat of a dire situation, a good way to tell you the mechanics at the start instead of having you look for everything waiting to die as soon as you press play. This is the only game I've ever played that makes going down a hill the most intense experience ever. The map system doesnt give you your exact location and really forces you to look around, observe your surroundings, and makes for a real survival experience. The momentum takes a bit to get used to, but other than that, this is a very well made game, and I'm nowhere close to being done with it

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												The unique real-world pacing of the game may be a tough pill to swallow, but if you can open your mind to feel the reality of isolation and being completely vulnerable while also being dependent of your environment, then be ready for a fullfilling and engaging experience. Being marooned and sick with the plague you will go through periods of frustration feeling helpless navigativing the island just trying to survive to the next day.  Though discovering new areas, clues to the mystery of the island, and finding new species of flora that will help you maintain your health are all satisfying moments that keep you moving forward.  Your worst enemy is most likely the danger of clumsily navigating steep cliffs or potentially drowing when caught in deep water, yet the silent presence of a single creature stalking you is never to far behind; adding a great sense of tension to the experience.  Also not keeping up your health with rest, medicines, and water, is a sure way to a quick demise.The feeling of helplessness being caught lost in the dead of night, waiting for morning to come.  Running and hiding from the island's lone predator while avoiding tumbling off a cliff and not dropping the much needed plant you just found, all wilst keeping your bearings on the nearest safe-haven.  These are some of the intense moments this unique survival game will deliver to you.The lack of way-points, weapons, and a traditional HUD, having to brutaly survey your map manually , and "realisic" way the character reacts and moves through movement may drive some gamers away.  But the sum of these parts, I feel, make for a completely unique and refreshing experience.Not without its flaws, but def one of my personal favorites of the year.  No guns-a-blazing, no special super-human abilities, no fellow travelers to help you here; just your wits and knowledge of the land will get you through this non-linear, challenging game of survival.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												When I first  tried this game for a few hours, I didn't like it. I thought the graphics were poor, the repetition of tasks irksome,   the fact that  my characters hands remained bloody however many times I  drank from water pools was ( and still is) annoying,  and the tension of trying to find somewhere to rest before dark or before the beast got me was  ever-present on  each new journey. Well... I have  restarted the game several times and, you could say, got used to it now, so my view point has amended. For one thing, I have discovered that the beast can be hidden from, if you are in the right terrain. He is not very bright, or maybe just short-sighted, as just hiding behind a rock near the waters edge works, so I feel there is more of a chance of survival once I hear that heart-beat. The limitation on how many  plant-species you can hold, and how many can be stored is another area of challenge, and I am getting desperate to find a successful match of two plants. All I have is 'one of each' in respect of mental acuity, strength,  agent y possibility, etc and all my six parking bays are full - and I need to  create some more  health boosters as well, so life is not easy! That is the point of the game, I suspect. If it were a breeze we would have lost interest and gone elsewhere before the map was half covered - and I haven't even covered a third of it yet. So, now I recommend it. Look past the minor irritants, try and keep one step ahead of dragon-creature ( why do some call it Milo I wonder?) keep looking for the right plants, and surviving WILL get easier sooner  or later... I hope..

												Miasmata is a fun and interesting game, but not without its flaws.Pros:-Disease survival aspect is done fairly well-World is beautiful and huge-Day/night cycles are realistic-Variety of interesting plants to find-Walking/gravity effect is also very realistic and makes the game more immersive (there's a real fear of momentum throwing you off a cliff instead of being able to magically stop at the last second.)Cons:-The "Creature" is a huge pain, and not in a good way. It feels broken most of the time and out of place.-No food is necessary, which takes away from the survival aspect a bit-A lot of the achievements are glitchy (search on the forums for the 3rd party fix before you start playing)In summary:If you're willing to put up with the annoyance of the Creature, it's worth picking up for people who like adventure/exploration and survival games.

												As pretty as it looks, Miasmata is literally un-playable because the walking mechanics are non-existent. The developers clearly tried to go for a realistic feel - your movement changes based on incline grades, your status, etc. - but unfortunately they forgot to sacrifice enough realism to play the game. Half the time your character walks like a penguin with polio, and as nice as it would be to take a slow waddle through the woods there's no place for that in the beginning of a survival game. While a bit of back-tracking is expected in this genre I found it too awkward to waddle from my home base to wherever I was headed again and again...not to mention only being able to hold one thing at a time, ignoring the pretty, well-designed map they gave you because everything's so close together...I could go on. If nothing else this teaches us to go back to basics and make things work before you make them pretty. (Like girlfriends. Or lawnmowers. Or ♥♥♥♥ing videogames.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Miasmata is a fantastic game that is wonderfully differentiated from rest of the survival genre. Everything about this game is presented simply, yet contains a hidden amount of depth.  Note that this is an exploration game first, and the "survival" aspects are kept to a minimum so you can focus on discovering new terrain. That's not to say you won't have tense moments as you try to stay alive, just that you likely won't be bored by metagamey tasks that slow down the pace.The obscenely simple controls make this an easy game for anyone to enjoy, while the mesh of mechanics and environment provide unexpected nuance. Setting off on your mission, the fugly looking graphics quickly become less bothersome and the task at hand becomes paramount and enjoyable. As a spoiler-free tip, movement in this game has a strong sense of momentum, much more than most fps games. Keep this in mind and get used to holding down the back/reverse key to slow yourself, lest your sprint down a trail turn into a tumble.The well-told story isn't bogged down with gobs of dialogue, and is instead presented in a subtle manner via the environment. Much like Dark Souls/Bloodborne, this gives great weight to in-game accomplishments and creates a strong sense of emotional connection.Lastly, anyone who struggles with reading maps or has a poor sense of direction should DEFINITELY check out this game. It'll up your real-world confidence and skill in short order.That a game of this quality was created by two people is a heckuva feat, and I eagerly look forward to their next creation.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												There is something really beautiful about a game like this.  There aren't detailed textures, there's no combat, there's chunks of gameplay that seem almost pointless (like the hatchets and apples), yet even with these quirks, it has captured my attention.  You are thrown into this island with no map and you must explore the island to find plants to make an anti-toxin.  You conduct research on plants and use cartography skills to learn more about your environment.  There are notes scattered around the island that give you information about the last people to explore this island.  It's a world that you must discover for yourself.You must walk along the paths that are carved or you'll probably fall down a cliff.  The map that you draw has actual topographical lines that indicate the elevation, so you can look for areas that are easy to navigate versus the cliffs that you need to avoid.  You must take care to avoid wandering at night unless you are prepared.  Unlike other games, there is almost zero visibility at night.  You can easily be carefully walking just to accidentally slip off a cliff to your death.Watch your map and compass, they are your best tools for survival.  If you just walk around picking up a bunch of plants, you'll undoubtedly get lost and you'll probably die.  The world is beautiful so take time to see everything.  Read the notes, look at the maps, piece everything together.  If you want a patient, calming, gorgeous gaming experience, get this game right now.  I wish more games were like this.  I love exploration and it's nice to be able to explore the island without distractions.  Except for that one thing, but it's not a huge deal.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2014/07/13/miasmata/Miasmata is a minimalistic survival game where you play the researcher Robert Hughes. You're cast away on an island, suffering from some kind of plague, and your aim is to find a cure as soon as possible. Luckily, there has already been some kind of a research team on the island but something has happened to them...I will start by saying that Miasmata is terribly beautiful. The graphics isn't always perfect but all in all the environments are amazing. I am incredibly impressed by the two brothers who made this game and the game engine on which it runs. Miasmata is immersive; My first night playing I couldn't stop until four in the morning, when I reluctantly realized it was getting light outside.To find a cure for your plague you have to find and research the plants and fungi on the island. It sounds trivial, but in Miasmata there is noone to hold your hand. You have to make progress using the notebooks you find from the earlier research team and on your own findings. The game is completely open world and you have no checkpoints or route to follow.There is also no automatic map. Instead, you draw your map using triangulation. Two known landmarks give you your position on the map and is what you use to update your map. Other than that you have to use your compass and your memory. (Orienteerers probably have an advantage!)You have no classic menus or inventory, instead you check your log book where all your notes and research is saved. You can also check on how you are feeling and take drugs for fever or other conditions.These three elements: Open world, the map system, and the log book creates a massively immersive feeling. Every menu, note or inventory has a "real" representation in the game.Other than that Miasmata is a creepy game which gave me some big adrenaline rushes. Instead of jumpscares, Miasmata provides the unnerving feeling of always being followed (and the panic of being discovered). Nature is also an enemy: Climbing mountains isn't easy and if you run too fast down a slope you will fall. Hopefully you know where you are when you are back in control, but in worst case you are lost and have to start looking for known landmarks again.On the negative side: I have to admit I was on several occations frustrated and annoyed when my assiduous exploration was interrupted. (By what, I will not mention...) I actually even rage quitted several times (but only to start it again after a minutes). At the same time, this is part of what is charming with the game and what creates intensity.There are also some small bugs, but nothing that can't be easily solved.A final warning to those who want to be able to close down a game quickly: You can save only at given save points. They are many and spread widely, but it can be good to know if you are the kind of gamer that have to be able to close down with just some seconds notice.7/10 petals

												I loved this game.  It's a first-person exploration / adventure game.  But instead of puzzles, there is a nifty mapping mechanic based on triangulation and finding landmarks and a search for plants that you can study and use to synthesize the medicines you need to survive.This game doesn't hold your hand and lead you through the plot.  There are no cut-scenes and no lousy voice-acting.  You have to piece the story together for yourself and decide where to go and what to do based on what you find as you explore the island.  And you can explore in pretty much any direction and any order you like.This is not your typical video-game power fantasy.  You start out as a character who is sick, can't swim, has trouble even walking around, and is in danger of tumbling down a steep incline and triggering a debilitating fever.  But the progression from sickness to health felt more empowering than the typical game that takes you from warrior to demigod.The graphics are not state-of-the-art.  This was made by a two-man team.  But the island is still a beautiful and interesting place to explore and the weather and time of day make a real difference in what you see and what you can do.  It feels like a real place that remains vivid in my mind months later.
