number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2014/07/13/miasmata/Miasmata is a minimalistic survival game where you play the researcher Robert Hughes. You're cast away on an island, suffering from some kind of plague, and your aim is to find a cure as soon as possible. Luckily, there has already been some kind of a research team on the island but something has happened to them...I will start by saying that Miasmata is terribly beautiful. The graphics isn't always perfect but all in all the environments are amazing. I am incredibly impressed by the two brothers who made this game and the game engine on which it runs. Miasmata is immersive; My first night playing I couldn't stop until four in the morning, when I reluctantly realized it was getting light outside.To find a cure for your plague you have to find and research the plants and fungi on the island. It sounds trivial, but in Miasmata there is noone to hold your hand. You have to make progress using the notebooks you find from the earlier research team and on your own findings. The game is completely open world and you have no checkpoints or route to follow.There is also no automatic map. Instead, you draw your map using triangulation. Two known landmarks give you your position on the map and is what you use to update your map. Other than that you have to use your compass and your memory. (Orienteerers probably have an advantage!)You have no classic menus or inventory, instead you check your log book where all your notes and research is saved. You can also check on how you are feeling and take drugs for fever or other conditions.These three elements: Open world, the map system, and the log book creates a massively immersive feeling. Every menu, note or inventory has a "real" representation in the game.Other than that Miasmata is a creepy game which gave me some big adrenaline rushes. Instead of jumpscares, Miasmata provides the unnerving feeling of always being followed (and the panic of being discovered). Nature is also an enemy: Climbing mountains isn't easy and if you run too fast down a slope you will fall. Hopefully you know where you are when you are back in control, but in worst case you are lost and have to start looking for known landmarks again.On the negative side: I have to admit I was on several occations frustrated and annoyed when my assiduous exploration was interrupted. (By what, I will not mention...) I actually even rage quitted several times (but only to start it again after a minutes). At the same time, this is part of what is charming with the game and what creates intensity.There are also some small bugs, but nothing that can't be easily solved.A final warning to those who want to be able to close down a game quickly: You can save only at given save points. They are many and spread widely, but it can be good to know if you are the kind of gamer that have to be able to close down with just some seconds notice.7/10 petals

content:
Posted: September 13, 2013
												This game is awesome. It really feels like you are wandering around - and getting lost! - on a smallish isnland. It's a survival horror game where you are seeking a cure for your disease - while something is hunting you. A group of scientists found the cure here, but they are a little bit dead now and the formula has to be re-discovered. Can you find a cure for the Plague before you become Purina Monster Chow?I also suggest that you read General Rye's negative review. His reasons for hating it are reasons why I like it. Yes, it seems like you are a 300 pound clod stumbling around an island - just like a real person, and not some uber-marine from your local FPS. You know what happens at night? It gets dark! Why the heck would you be wandering around in the dark when there's some freaky monster wandering around? Also, the game penalizes you for being awake all day (a neat  thing that few games do), with moments of exhaustion, which can be remedied by (strangely enough) sleeping!I'd like to see a sequel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												Miasmata is a curious game I completed over the course of a week or so, having watched a fair number of the playthrough videos by Mesh of Mack & Mesh fame on youtube.  It seemed like the perfect game for my mood at the time, nothing too heavy or intense, no fiddly controls to figure out or the wonderful task of re-binding keys due to being left-handed!  And what a game it turned out to be.For the most part an island exploration simulator, where you wander through valleys, over mountaintops and into dense jungle, Miasmata can be a theraputic, calming experience.  Aside from the task of having to locate and synthesize a number of plants into drugs to cure your character of an unknown plague (admittedly not a relaxing expeience for the guy you're playing), there are no constant swarms of enemies charging towards you or restrictive timeframe placed upon your actions, besides the passing of day into night. Of course this changes to a degree a certain number of days into the game, when another 'element' is added to the experience, which certainly got my blood pumping on a few occasions!  Having a beast roaming the island with you adds an air of menace to proceedings, as you learn to be stealthier, sneakier or downright panicky in order to esacape its clutches when you cross paths.In truth, the beast is only a small part of the joy of Miasmata, as I gained the most pleasure from simply roaming over the terrain, triangulating my way across the map in search of the next hut, piece of vital information, or important plant for examination.  If you have a powerful enough system, the island is a wonder to behold, if somewhat sparse if you are used to running into streams of characters to interact with.I couldn't recommend this game highly enough, for the time I invested into it.  Buy it when it's on a Steam sale like I did and enjoy :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is an interesting survival/adventure game.  Exploring the island was kind of neat.  Trying to find all the landmarks and get the entire map to show up is a bit of a challenge on its own.  There's a few buildings scattered around that you'll run into here and there that also have notes in them to give you an idea of what happened since you're all alone and don't have any idea what you're doing there.  I also liked collecting the various plants to craft painkillers and other drugs.  It almost made me wish there were more things to collect and craft than there are.My biggest complaint is a possible small spoiler, so I'll hide that next.  I found it kind of tedious once the creature starts showing up.  I was initially kind of excited the first time I saw it.  I tried to hide, but that didn't work out so well since it seemed to home in straight on me.  Pretty much when it first appears, it's not so bad since it only shows up once in a great while, but when you start progressing on your "main quest" it shows up more often.  By the time you're nearly finished with the quest, it's virtually impossible to avoid the thing.  I also had what I'd call worse than 50/50 success in hiding from it too even when I was in a spot that I was completely hidden from it at all times and not making any noise.  I even had a few times that I jammed myself between a tree and the side of a cliff that was completely hidden by leaves and grass and it still kept trying to walk straight at me even though we couldn't see each other (I know where it was walking since I had the skill that tracks the creature when you don't move).  The next small thing is when night falls and you don't have a light source, you're pretty much screwed.  It's completely black and you mostly end up literally rolling down hills on your face and/or falling into the water where you're likely to drown.  You learn real quick not to try going out at night without a torch in hand and another one nearby to take its place.Overall I found this to be an enjoyable game in spite of the complaints I have above.  It's worth a play through if you like exploring the unknown.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This was one of the most immersive games I have played in a long time.You are dropped on a very large island with very little to use for direction. Most of the game is silent except for your own footsteppes and atmosphere, but depending on where you go, soothing songs will play. It gave me a strong sense of being alone, except for the terrifying creature that could find you at any moment.Rather than give my full straight oppinion of the game, let me give my view of the "issues" that others have had with Miasmata.First, is the creature. I've heard many say they looks stupid and isn't scary. It's certainly an odd looking thing, but when you're just walking through the woods, and hear some twigs breaking in the distance, and search to find a heavily camoufaged thing stalking up on you, it's scary as hell. And it really chases you too, and can kill you in seconds if you aren't careful.Second is the movement. I applauded this game for it's realistic simulation of movement. It takes getting used to, because it is very different from other games out there, but it makes you feel much more vulnerable, and only added to the immersion for me. In real life, if you tried going down a 45 degree incline at any speed other than tiny steps, you could easily slip and fall. People are mad because they can't sprint full speed downhill without natual consequences. It's called momentum, and even a small incline will speed you up if you run down it. People who complained about this clearly don't get out often.There are a couple real minor downsides to the game that I have seen mentioned, such as not being able to look at your map at night if you are holding something. Some animations are a bit stiff or mechanical, and I would love to see those polished to improve immersion.As a conclusion, Miasmata is a very different experience from most games. It was a wonderful break from shooters and heavy storylined games. When playing I felt a great sense of freedom, isolation, loneliness. Most of the game is quite relaxing, and anyone looking for a fun, different experience should try this.

												Miasmata was made by two brothers. This game is about an island which you are stuck on...due to the fact that your people banished you. Your boat crashes on this island and you find out that a people once lived here. They are all dead now, and recently. You are sick...sick to the point of death within hours. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												It took me well over a year to finish this game, but I'm glad I finally did because it was phenomenal. This is hands down the most unique game I've ever played. A true indie at heart, both in its feel, design and execution. Instead of blatantly placing you on an island full of monstrocities with gun in hand, you are unarmed, with only one menace stalking you. That's the initial picture at least. It soon becomes clear that much more to fear. One of the greatest things about this game is how it is actually possibly to become utterly lost. This sounds weird, but in almost every other game there some way of tracking that gives you the secure feeling that you know where you are. Most games have a minimap of some kind, a map with a marker, or something else. Miasmata has a blank sheet of paper. And no matter how much you explore, this piece of paper will stay blank until you actively start drawing a map on it. Doing so is not easy: you need to triangulate your location by use of landmarks. You might be in a new zone without a clue what to do: none of the landmarks are familiar to you, and the area isn't charted. One of the creepiest things in the game was leaving your outpost and explore this uncharted land, knowing that you would become lost within a minute, struggling to find your way back, and possibly at the mercy of this beast. For me that's the true power of this game.A second greatest thing about this game is the fact that you're doing something you'll never do in any other game: harvest and research plants to make a cure for an illness (some RPGs may do this in a quest but this is an entire game based around it). It sounds horribly boring, but combined with the tension this game gives you, it is an absolutely interesting task. Those who've played this game might recall the luminous algae you had to find: I was utterly terrified during that section. Third, the walking and climbing mechanics are amazing. This is the only game where it really felt as if you had momentum when you ran. Running at full speed really felt like running, the risk of tripping adding to the feeling. It actually feels as if you struggle to climb up a mountain. It actually feels as if you put your weight against the slope of a mountain when you are descending. A fourth aspect is how the story is much more than meets the eye. Admittedly I didn't care much for it while playing because I lost track over the months (partly based on the one negative thing, the repetitiveness), but reading back some of the ideas and interpretations on the forum here really opened a much more complex picture than what I would've thought while playing. TL;DR I can rant on and on about this for about the length of a small essay but I'll leave it at this: if you enjoy a good indie title, try this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 14, 2013
												Miasmata is a First-Person Survival Game with a strong focus on discovery and exploration. You are a criminal (forgot the name, sorry about that), who gets banished on an island. You also are sick and have to find different plants and fungi to create a cure and then escape the island. But you are not alone. A creature follows you across the island and tries to kill you. Will you survive to find a cure ?Miasmata has the same combat mechanics as popular horror-games like Amnesia and Outlast. There are none. The only thing you can do during creature encounters is run and hide, which creates a tension and you sometimes almost go mental, because the creature is pretty deadly and hard to escape from. But honestly, I am a bit disappointed by the creatures AI and the spawning points. Sometimes you run away from the beast, just to encounter it a couple hundred meters further again, this time infront of you. Or one time it spawned on a small island at the beach and was unable to swim, so it could just look at it without any danger. I would not call such cases bugs, but they brake the illusion of a superior enemy and quickly show the mechanics behind it. Still, the fact, that creature encounters are quite rare at times and your hearth starts to beat, when the creature is near, builds tention and you got a good chance to escape.But 98 % there is gameplay without fleeing from the creature. In this time you have to find plants with which you can create different kinds of medicines. With those, you can cure injuries (which can kill you after some time), can boost your stamina, strench, perception and ultimately cure your illness, which makes you a pretty weak human being. Without any boosts of medicine, your swimming and sprintingrange are very limited and noticing your worst enemy is up to you. But collecting and finding plants to create medicine is necessary and ultimately the goal of the game.Finding very specific plants for specific cures can be very difficulte. The main problem besides surviving is orientation. You have to draw your own map through triangulation. You do this with markpoint, represented through statues, buildings, ruins, and pillars, which you find scattered over the map. Whenever you can see two such points, you draw your surroundings. This can be pretty difficulte and forgetting to draw your map can get you lost pretty quickly. The fact, that you do not see your position on the map without boosting your perception, makes it even more difficulte.From time to time, you find mappieces in huts, which sometimes show you the location on your map, sometimes just hint at it. Finding specific plants can be really annoying, but also rewarding, when you finally get your piece of the cure or another boost to run faster or longer.Graphicaly, the game is mediocre at best, aiming at a realistic graphic style. But honestly, it never bothered me, the landscape looks nice, little bunnies run away from you, butterflies and birds fly around, you hear the wind blowing. Everything is very athmospheric and the graphics fit. There are games out there with way better graphics, but look also way ugglier.Verdict: Miasmata is a very athmospheric survival game. It builds a feeling of loneliness, in a cheerfull world, while being hunted by a fearsome creature. The survival aspects could be done better and finding plants can be ridiculous and getting lost is daily business. But despite these flaws, Miasmata is a solid game, which deserves your playtime.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Buy? Likely-=TL;DR=-Miasmata is a unique, first-person survival exploration game where the player must stave off symptoms of a deadly fever that accelerates thirst, weakens the body and somehow either through hallucination or some sort of attraction affect, spawns a deadly, nearly indescribable horror simply referred to the creature. This beast is basically invincible, faster than you and can kill you in two claw swipes. The player must use a combination of cartography and chemistry to find and use plant life across the island of Eden to mitigate and eventually cure his ailment. Miasmata enforces the fact that you are a frail person, collecting herbs while managing thirst and fatigue, and gave me a sense of dread and fear that no horror game has ever given me.-=Presentation=-This is both arguably the best and worse part of the game. Upon getting off the canoe at the start, you're present a beautifully lit island with loads of flora, ambience and world design that immediately immerses you in the world. Yet, the minute you turn around to look at your boat or bother to look at your hands are the ground below you, the models and textures are only barely better than a PS2 era game. It's extremely jarring to see a world that looks much like Skyrim with ENB and flora mods, but with textures only moderately better than Morrowind. Standing water around the island looks great, but beyond that, there is no volumetric water: The water you drink from ponds is invisible and the water poured from pitchers are literally solid beads that would only look like water from a far distance. Also, the draw distance and level of detail is kind of atrocious for a game that looks like this - world  details (rocks, plants) within 8-12 feet in front of you update model quality or pop-in out of nowhere like some sort of hologram effect from a sci-fi movie. It severely ruins the immersive experience the developers were trying to create, and it's strange why there is no included options to manage level of detail for stronger PCs.In spite of all the visual presentation issues, you can often find many screenshot worthy moments as the sun light, god rays, water reflection, cloud and tree shadows have an effect on the medium-low quality environment, proving that lighting effects can drastically improve the look of a game.The audio presentation is pretty good. There are appropriate sound effects for any action in the game from walking on dirt, wood, or rocks, to swimming, drinking water to swinging a weapon and opening up the map or journal. There are occasional sound cues when turning on lights. The majority of you sound will be in the form of blowing wind, rushing waters, lively critters, and of course, the roars of the godforsaken beast and the heartbeat the PC has the moment it gets near you.  The occasional music that plays as you discover camps and various settlements is of a light, symphonic, ambient mood.-=Gameplay=-I can't believe I said so much about the presentation - the gameplay and mechanics are always the most important factors of a game to me. You are Robert Hughes, and you must cure your plague. You will gradually find notes and clues about harvesting ingredients, discovering locations, and using cartography to map your position. Yes, Cartography. There are no waypoints or Skyrim-esque "quest objective is right here!" map markers here, though campsites, statues and other landmarks are marked on your paper map as you properly locate them via triangulation or partial maps across the island. It is easy to get lost among the trees and mountains and it is generally best to use landmarks, trails, coastlines, and various "world formations" in tandem with collected partial maps and your compass to get an idea of where you are and where you are going.You can pick up and throw items like fruit, rocks, axes, knives, and household objects, though it's all there to remind you that you are a frail person - none of these except from fire made from torches are even remotely useful in dealing with the creature. Combat only exists for the creature. This means you must hide or bore the creature enough to get away from it. You can run, but it's not always suggested as it can catch up to you almost immediately. It stalks you slowly when you walk and it's best to look around and find a good path to move, before finally running to a building to hide in or a object to hide behind. The problem with running in this game is not only the creature faster than you, but you are easily fatigued unless you prepared yourself with endurance medicine you made from plant life. Plus, Robert has a bit of a "Sonic syndrome" where he has a hard time running up hills and sprints madly down hills. You have to manage this inertia by carefully finding proper pathways around and avoiding steep falls, since he is a clumsy idiot who can barely control his movement apparently, and will contract a fever that will blur your vision and slow your movement if you fall. It's a bit of a nuisance to control the character and it will definitely make many gamers dislike Miasmata. Though, if the game had a normal first person movement system, much of the tension would be lost since you're no longer accidentally running into the creature and not struggling to get up hills. Because of that, I cautiously welcome it - after all I would probably use slopes to increase my speed if I needed too.The bulk of the game is finding herbs and fungi to research for medicines, drinkable temporary buffs, injectable permanent buffs and eventually the cure. You get clues on what to use from notes around the island and personal examinations on plants. Just be careful with your limited storage bin, 3 holdable plants and ease of dropping them if you trip and fall.-=Summary=-Miasmata is a tense survival game that definitely helped scratch my itch for exploration. It offered an non-combat experience I've never had before and made me legitimately scared of the creature until I knew how to exploit it (unfortunately, he more annoying than scary in the near end game). I'm definitely glad I played it, though I wish there was an improved, modded, or sequel version. Though, it's movement mechanics and map system will turn off many gamers. Definitely play this if you're looking for exploration, survival and tension.

Along with that, the character feels like he's on slippery ice; I understand that the developers wanted to deliver a feeling of running out of control down the hill, but it sucks when it happens even on a level surface.HDR is so extreme, looking at sun makes the whole vision so dark that you feel like you are looking at moon in the night. But the game is graphically inspiring and impressive at times.Anyway, I could forgive all of the problems, if the game did not ended up crashing and made me waste an hour. I simply don't have the luxury time to play that again. Then I said "Okay, that's it."I liked the game, I even tried to love it, but couldn't and maybe it's my bad luck. Still, it's a nice game and not recommending it would be shame so my thumb is up.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Miasmata is one of those rare gems - a somber, deliberately slow paced and thoughtful game that somehow still manages to make your heart race with both excitement and fear. While it is somewhat janky and buggy at times, the thrill of exploring the island and unraveling its mysteries is a delight. The lack of gameiness is one of the greames greatest strengths - it totally adheres to its first person perspective and does away with UI marks, HUD clutter and arbitrary collectables. Being alone on the island trying to survive means the game won't hold your hand the whole way; see something interesting on your travels? Write it down. Find interesting flora somewhere? Memorize how to get there. The game immerses you completely in its world thanks to its gameplay systems.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												Do you want to be a botanist? In Miasmata you walk among forests earnestly designed to resemble real forests. You get to roam a range of different kinds of these true-to-life woods.  A perfect day goes something like this: You experience hiking along trails, laboring up slopes, struggling to cross ravines, and traverse many foothills. Along your way, you drink from freshwater streams and sketch in your map. When you cross into a forest you’ve never entered before, you collect some unfamiliar vegetation, make some basic notes of its appearance in your notebook, and plan to examine it in detail later.  You witness that landscape gradually sink from dusk into the deep blackness of night – the kind of pitch blackness that prevents you from seeing your hand in front of your face.  After a struggle back to camp, you collapse into a cot, to fall asleep immediately. Before long, you wake up to greet the dawn with a refreshed desire to head out once more. You get to be a cartographer, a botanist, and a hiker in this game. Funnily enough, it’s actually impossible and dangerous to try and walk straight up a mountain. Taking the hiking trail is infinitely faster, easier, and less likely to send you plummeting. This isn’t forced. If you want, you can still try to scale vertically, and you’ll make it 70% of the time. But the mechanics and the way your pace preserves momentum, make it quite a bit more beneficial to take any apparent path. (Again, not by invisible walls or magic “fall down” timers if you wander off the rails. This is based on slipperiness and momentum. They are your movement system to learn and to master. It isn’t glorious, fun, or easy. It is a skill to manipulate it to your advantage.) There aren’t always paths, but you learn to glance at the forest in front of you and judge instantly just what is a bad idea and what is a good way to navigate the direction you desire. You will be going “just around this one ridge” a lot. And that makes the landscape something you actually interact with, rather than punch through.  It also makes keeping track of where you are a non-trivial objective.Being a cartographer is relatively simple. It’s as straightforward as pointing at a landmark, then pointing at another, and using their angles to determine (triangulate) where you must be in relation to them. Then your map will color in automatically. It’s recorded realistically, showing the angles you are taking on your map to measure your position or the direction of another object. Your map is also blissfully magnifiable whenever you want to peer at it. Keep in mind, I said this is simple, but I did not say it is effortless. Cartography requires knowing where other objects are, before you can fill in your own location. This requires methodically stopping at every new viewing position, and continuously recording each landmark you spot. Trees are constantly blocking your view to landmarks. If you walk a few feet down a ridge, good luck having a clear sight line. Contrast to being a botanist: simple, easy, and enjoyable. Snip a stem. Examine it at a lab bench. Learn its properties. Instantly use it to help treat yourself at another work bench. You’ll automatically take some proper notes about its plant anatomy, and highlight how it can be used in a notebook full of nicely illustrated pages devoted to this task. I can’t think of another game that addresses my very potent desire to be a botanist like this.I don’t think this game will work well for many people, but I (really really really) like where it is going. I just wish there were more games trying what Miasmata is trying.

												First, this game will not be for everyone.  It's a horror/suspense game with FPS type controls.  The main driver throughout the game is that you suffer from fevers.  To combat these fevers, you must craft medicine from plants you collect on the island.  Your in game character is no superman.  He has liminted stamina and too much strenuous activity will bring on a fever which could result in death.Added to that you have the constant threat of the island monster.  Plus, you start out with no map.  You must create it using topography and triangulation.  It's a really neat system that I've haven't seen used in any other game.  As you play, you gradually map out the entire island.Overally, I loved this game.  The pace, the constant threat of fevers and monsters, and the general weakness of the in-game character made the whole experience suspenseful and tense.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												Do you want to be a botanist? In Miasmata you walk among forests earnestly designed to resemble real forests. You get to roam a range of different kinds of these true-to-life woods.  A perfect day goes something like this: You experience hiking along trails, laboring up slopes, struggling to cross ravines, and traverse many foothills. Along your way, you drink from freshwater streams and sketch in your map. When you cross into a forest you’ve never entered before, you collect some unfamiliar vegetation, make some basic notes of its appearance in your notebook, and plan to examine it in detail later.  You witness that landscape gradually sink from dusk into the deep blackness of night – the kind of pitch blackness that prevents you from seeing your hand in front of your face.  After a struggle back to camp, you collapse into a cot, to fall asleep immediately. Before long, you wake up to greet the dawn with a refreshed desire to head out once more. You get to be a cartographer, a botanist, and a hiker in this game. Funnily enough, it’s actually impossible and dangerous to try and walk straight up a mountain. Taking the hiking trail is infinitely faster, easier, and less likely to send you plummeting. This isn’t forced. If you want, you can still try to scale vertically, and you’ll make it 70% of the time. But the mechanics and the way your pace preserves momentum, make it quite a bit more beneficial to take any apparent path. (Again, not by invisible walls or magic “fall down” timers if you wander off the rails. This is based on slipperiness and momentum. They are your movement system to learn and to master. It isn’t glorious, fun, or easy. It is a skill to manipulate it to your advantage.) There aren’t always paths, but you learn to glance at the forest in front of you and judge instantly just what is a bad idea and what is a good way to navigate the direction you desire. You will be going “just around this one ridge” a lot. And that makes the landscape something you actually interact with, rather than punch through.  It also makes keeping track of where you are a non-trivial objective.Being a cartographer is relatively simple. It’s as straightforward as pointing at a landmark, then pointing at another, and using their angles to determine (triangulate) where you must be in relation to them. Then your map will color in automatically. It’s recorded realistically, showing the angles you are taking on your map to measure your position or the direction of another object. Your map is also blissfully magnifiable whenever you want to peer at it. Keep in mind, I said this is simple, but I did not say it is effortless. Cartography requires knowing where other objects are, before you can fill in your own location. This requires methodically stopping at every new viewing position, and continuously recording each landmark you spot. Trees are constantly blocking your view to landmarks. If you walk a few feet down a ridge, good luck having a clear sight line. Contrast to being a botanist: simple, easy, and enjoyable. Snip a stem. Examine it at a lab bench. Learn its properties. Instantly use it to help treat yourself at another work bench. You’ll automatically take some proper notes about its plant anatomy, and highlight how it can be used in a notebook full of nicely illustrated pages devoted to this task. I can’t think of another game that addresses my very potent desire to be a botanist like this.I don’t think this game will work well for many people, but I (really really really) like where it is going. I just wish there were more games trying what Miasmata is trying.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												One of the most memorable PC experiences I've had. It's not tightly polished, it's fairly simplistic, and it's slow - but it's immersive, challenging, and different than anything I've played.GAMEPLAY: Using a standard FPS control scheme, you explore an island searching for the cure to a disease which afflicts you. Symptoms manifest themselves in the form of fatigue (you will drown faster while swimming and lose your footing easier when climbing), suffer from blurry vision, and eventually die. You must stave off these effects by crafting medicines out of plants found on the island, of which there are many types, and you have to collect and research each one to see what it does. You also have to drink water, which you can find in ponds, pitchers in cabins, or in your canteen. Dehydration causes onset of the symptoms above. Strangely, and somewhat jarringly, you don't have to eat at all.Perhaps the most unique aspect of this game is the navigational aspect. You will find small snippets of maps, but most of the mapping will have to be done manually in the form of triangulation - pinpointing your location in relation to two landmarks (statues, cabins, and tents). It's the largest factor in determining your route, as you will be forced to stay within sight of landmarks. It creates a feeling of helplessness and empowerment simultaneously - you will be walking blind with little clue where to go, until you add a little bit more to your map, which is a great feeling every time. Your compass is a vital suplement to the map, as it's easy to become lost. The game doesn't handhold, and when you lose your path, there's little recourse except to take your best guess as to where to go. This is most dangerous when falling, as the screen blurs, you become turned around, and drop whatever items you were carrying. It has the potential to be fatal, especially when in uncharted territory. Another useful tool is your watch, which you must use to ensure you aren't caught in the jungle at night - visibility is extremely limited, to the point where it is almost entirely pointless to travel at night. This is another large factor in determining your travel schedule, as you will want to be in a safe place before nightfall.Of course, there's another danger on the island in the form of a monster that stalks the island, against which you are defenceless. It has the potential to throw off your plans, as getting away from it will be paramount - sometimes necessitating flight into unmarked territory.VISUALS: The game looks very nice. It goes for a realistic style, which looks great for the environment elements - rocks, water, etc. Living creatures look a little stinted, but by no means bad, and certainly not immersion breaking. Reaching the coastline and looking out onto the water is one of the most beautiful parts of this game. While most of the game takes place in nature, there are a few man-made elements that stand out visually - ruins in the jungle, for instance.AUDIO: Serves the game extremely well. There's a soft ambient soundtrack that underlines the experience, making exploring the island strangely calming, despite the need for survival. Sound effects are great too - perhaps the most memorable being the pulsing and ringing that occurs when taking a fall. A sound you will quickly identify is the pounding of the character's heart when the monster approaches, its intensity indicating the creature's proximity. It's a very quiet game, but each sound serves to add a little something to the experience. STORY: The focus is on survival and escaping the island, but there's a tale to be uncovered about the protagonist's past, as well as that of the island - who had been exploring the island and why, and how they came to disappear. It comes off mostly as context for the gameplay, which isn't a bad thing, especially considering the story is satisfying to uncover in all of its little bits and pieces, conveyed almost entirely by optional notes.This game is a slow burn, and has challenges unlike those I've seen in other games. Which is why I enjoyed it so thoroughly - it's a chance to explore a beautiful island on your own, and craft strategies for survival. It's hard to say, exactly, what type of demographic I'd recommend this game to - perhaps horror fans looking for a new angle, or those who like exploration games - but I know that I would for sure, as I had a great time with this game.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2013
												This is not an action game: there is no combat although there is an animal on the island which will kill you if you fail to hide from it.This is a game of exploration: you are stranded on an island, suffering from a plague.  The cure is on this Island although those that made it are all dead.  You explore the island, mapping it as you go, searching for the plants required to create the cure (as well as the scientists notes with regards as to which plants you actually require).  In your diseased state you are weak.  A slight fall, dehydration or lack of sleep will lead to a fever...left untreated the fever will kill you.  You can use various plants around the island to synthesise drugs to combat the fever or to increase your strenght, endurance and awareness.In this game it is the environment which is your enemy: the island is a mountainous, jungle environment full of steap slopes: in Miasmata your body has momentum and navigating all of those hills becomes a matter of life or death.  You will slide, trip and fall but it all feels very natural.I loved this game: the island setting is well realised...the sounds of the environment are very well done, while the lighting is fantastic.The game was made by two people, with an engine they built specifically for the purpose.  There are rough patches to the graphics but I can honestly say that I never noticed them unless I went looking for them.I highly recommend it, but it may not be to everyone's taste.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												I bought this game when it first was announced. I want to make my position very clear on it. I like it. I don't think I would tell a friend to buy it, but I like the game enough to play it from time to time. The graphics were fantastic when I first bought it, but by today's standards, not so much. I'm not one to value graphics over gameplay, though. So, what's the gameplay like? I think a curator put it best. "Guerilla Botany" was what they called it. You use flowers which you can pick up around you to synthesize medications, and use them to better your health, all while avoiding a monster. The monster was a huge selling point for the game, but he's not all that big or scary, or even that big of a threat. Bottom line, if you don't mind that this game hasn't been updated in forever, and you like games that make you feel lonely and immersed, this might be the game for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Miasmata is survival geocaching. You're a plague-stricken scientist who must create a cure by finding specific plants on a remote island, via the use of exploration, maps, clues and cartography.The central gameplay mechanic is unique and very appealing to me. I've always wanted a game that did this and I'm happy to say that it does this part extremely well.The terrain is nicely detailed and there's plenty of little animals on the island, which really bring it to life. I thoroughly enjoyed exploring the island, discovering the plants and uncovering the story.Consequently I am recommending this game, but it is important to say that there are a lot of problems. This is far from a polished game. Notable things are:* The game crashed twice and then crashed again during the end. Somewhat anti-climatic, but at least it worked after restarting the game.* After closing the map/journal the game would very frequently ignore my mouse movements. Meaning I would have to open and close the map/journal again. This got extremely frustrating. The map and journal are well designed, but the bug put me off using them as much as I wanted to.* The character can somehow climb up very steep terrain, but will also fall on easily navigable terrain. It doesn't make a lot of sense.* Many floating trees.* Can't pick up two of the same plant.* During animations the colour of objects can change, which is a bit immersion breaking.* Creating a duplicate of an item you already own will just overwrite that item, with no warning or explanation.* Terrain was constantly popping in and redrawing, even just a couple of metres in front of me.* The terrain diversity is quite limited, which is further worsened by the colour draining. The unique terrain features that do exist are memorable and make the island seem more alive, but the amount of them is very small. It would have been nice to have a waterfall, clearing, cave, tunnel, proper cliff, massive tree, etc.My final issue with the game is subjective, so I'm not including it in the list. I didn't care for the creature at all. I felt that it was an unnecessary feature that added very little to the game and became an annoyance very quickly. It appears very early in the game and will happily stand there in the middle of the path, so there's no suspense or mystery. The game's description says the creature will stalk you for miles, which sounds amazing, but I didn't see any proof of that happening. If someone said it randomly appeared in a random location near you, I'd have no evidence against that.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2013
												Back when Myst first came out, there was a Fox Trot cartoon in which Jason hacked up a version of Myst that was exactly the same as the original, except that velociraptors were chasing the player. That's a pretty good description of Miasmata.Exploration is the driving mechanic of the game, and in this respect, the island of Eden is a paradise. Every part of the island is unique, with hills, rivers, swamps, ancient ruins, and dense foliage of many kinds. The lighting and water effects are very impressive. At the same time, Eden's beauty is tempered by its dangers. Fatigue, sickness, and the terror of being stalked are conveyed in an organic and immersive fashion, which makes them all the scarier.Miasmata is a beautiful sandbox experience. I also found it very frightening, at times. Perhaps not everyone will find it as scary as I did, but anyone who loves exploring will find it very engaging.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I'd recommend Miasmata especially to players who like exploration, don't need a constant objective solving and like something new.You start off stranded on an island, infected with the plaque and in search of the cure for the plaque. Luckily you are on an island on which the cure for the plaque was researched. As sick as you are your bodies’ condition isn't good at all. You can't run very far without getting out of breath, swimming is beyond question and falling down a hill becomes a regular thing. After a while (or after falling down) your condition gets even worse and you start having fever. But fortunately there is plenty of plants and herbs that can be manufactured to a temporary medicament against the fever.Besides the fever medicament you may also make temporary as well as permanent body enhancement medicaments, which allow you to run faster, to run a greater distance and even to swim.Recipes for the different meds just as parts of the story behind the research team are found all over the island on certain campsites.As you progress through the island searching for the cure you can't miss the beast, a creature which sole purpose it is to obstruct you. As soon as it hits you your fever worsens and after the second hit you lose you consciousness. There are several possibilities to escape from the beast and you have to escape from it not being able to harm or even killing it.Another major part of the game is to triangulate your position and map the island. Without triangulating it is very hard to find your way to different parts of the island so triangulate as often as possible. If you can't find any known landmark and need to know where you are, you can drink a tonic you are able to mix to get temporary the ability to know where you are on the map.By finishing the game you might get behind the story of the island, the research team and yourself.Regarding the graphics:It isn't the best looking game BUT the weather and the different times of day are excellent conveyed. You always get really the feeling that it is as late as it is. (For example 10 pm is very different to 10 am and sunny weather is very different to a storm).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												This game started out amazing.  There were obscure hints to a dangerous beast (TV series "Lost" obsuce).  One of which were weapons, and multiple ways to attack.  Another was danger sense.  There were others too, which I won't spoil.  But what I will spoil is that the beast mechanic is horrible.  There's an "at bay" attack with a specific weapon.  It kinda works, but really janky.  Other attacks do nothing to it.  I've tried a variety of weapons, including blades, thrown and swung, and they do nothing.  The beast moves like one of the worst AI's I've seen, getting stuck easily around obsticles.  It moves slowly whenever I am facing it (seems to move quickly if I turn and run, but I've never seen this).  It's just really scarry until you fight it once, then it's not scarry.  The hide mechanic is horrible, because, while it's usually not hard to hide, it takes agonizingly long for it to patrol away.  If it patrols away at all.  I've stayed ducked in the brush for entirely too long with it just doing the same lap seemingly perpetually.  I've not stayed a day cycle, but multiple in game hours and seen this.  TO MAKE THIS CLEAR: I AM NOT COMPLAINING THAT THE BEAST IS TOO HARD!  I'm complaning that the mechanics of the beast make me really not even want to play any more.  I like the idea of a threat like this, just not how it was executed.  It shoudl require more skill to avoid it, and less patience (patience should be a big part of the experience, but at times infinite patience holding CTRL is too much).  Honestly, the beast got my adrenaline up before I ever encountered it, and now when I encounter it I get a feeling similar to a game bug.  Knowing the experience will completely remove emersion from me, and that if I die, it will feel more like having to restart because of a game glitch than because I played poorly.  The beast needs massively revamped.The other problem is with the map.  The way you draw lines while doing cartography, and then how the camera auto zooms for you is frustrating given the number of times you are encouraged to do it.   And I could get past that, but it's an annoying time sync.  What sucks is that 40% of the time I look at the map, it locks mouse movement, which is completely vital to the game.  I can get it back by opening and closing inventory.  But it's buggy, removes immersion, and can lead to problems for your character if you start moving and sliding down something when you expected to mouse turn before the drop, or if you are frantically wayfinding while trying to beat a timer (like potion, night, or stalking beast).  This is flat out buggy.  It shoudl be fixed, but it's the creature that makes me not want to play.  I was still playing a lot in one sitting even with this glitch.The terrain and movement.  There are a lot of complaints about the realistic troubles the engine gives you with moving on terrain.  Having done a bunch of hiking myself (not that I'm a pro outdoorsman by any means), a lot of what they simulate is pretty realistic.  But people aren't complaining as much about realism as what's fun for real life isn't necessarily fun for a game.  I agree with that philosophy, but, I do think the realistic terrain dangers are a positive for the game.  Sometimes it's a little jankey feeling, but only a little, and not often.  It's really good and serves the game in my opinion.  Now it would be a horrible feature for your average 1st person shooter, but for this game it'e completely engaging, and I quite enjoy that.The premice and story thus far are pretty cool.  I do want to reccomend the game, but for what I said in the first paragraph, I cannot (the second paragraph is stikes against the game, but it's the first paragraph alone that makes me not recommend it).EDIT:I did play the game to completion, and messed around with it a bit more after that.  I forgot to mention numerous rendering issues (vector points stretched in front of the camera constantly, odd strobing that seemed unintentional), but your experience may be different.  Anyways, this game created an experience very unique to itself.  I still don't recommend it mostly because of the beast feels so glitch-y.  But it was a memorable experience, and offered good qualities no other game has.  I will be very interested to see their new game, and will most likely get it.  I certainly think the company is worth keeping an eye on, and I commend them for creating their own experience.  If you are still reading, I hope you have a good idea about if this game is for you.

I don't even need to hunt to hunt or anything that adds any vague interest to the trips, just lots and lots of walking, and lots and lots of falling over. I paid £12 for this.

												This game was recommended to by a forum friend, and at first I was very sceptical. Wow did this game surprise: This game has got to be the most incredible non-violent game I have ever played. To survive you must find the right plants to make pills and tonics for various purposes, from keeping the symptoms of the Plague away, to an extra boost to your system to sprint or swim for longer. All the while in fear of being found by a mysterious creature. There is something about quietly hunting for glowing algae at night one minute, and sprinting full pace down a narrow jungle path with only your burning bunch of twigs as your light the next!....

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17, 2013
												This is not an action game: there is no combat although there is an animal on the island which will kill you if you fail to hide from it.This is a game of exploration: you are stranded on an island, suffering from a plague.  The cure is on this Island although those that made it are all dead.  You explore the island, mapping it as you go, searching for the plants required to create the cure (as well as the scientists notes with regards as to which plants you actually require).  In your diseased state you are weak.  A slight fall, dehydration or lack of sleep will lead to a fever...left untreated the fever will kill you.  You can use various plants around the island to synthesise drugs to combat the fever or to increase your strenght, endurance and awareness.In this game it is the environment which is your enemy: the island is a mountainous, jungle environment full of steap slopes: in Miasmata your body has momentum and navigating all of those hills becomes a matter of life or death.  You will slide, trip and fall but it all feels very natural.I loved this game: the island setting is well realised...the sounds of the environment are very well done, while the lighting is fantastic.The game was made by two people, with an engine they built specifically for the purpose.  There are rough patches to the graphics but I can honestly say that I never noticed them unless I went looking for them.I highly recommend it, but it may not be to everyone's taste.

Posted: March 29, 2013
												This game felt like reading a good novel. It is well written, the story is compelling and it drags you within. You feel sick when the character does.At the same time, it is better than the best thriller movie I ever watched. More thrilling than playing resident evil. There have been times when I "heard the heart beats" and just exited the game and said "enough!".In most games with a thriller theme, there is blood and gore and you typically are holding a gun in your hand. You already have an adrenaline rush and are up to the task ahead. This game, however, is about calmly and peacefully collecting flowers, and when it escalates, you are sick, weak, totally defenseless and vulnerable. You have way too much to lose in your hand and there is no such a thing as being ready for the challenge.This is an addictive thriller novel that I would recommend to everyone.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												One of the most memorable PC experiences I've had. It's not tightly polished, it's fairly simplistic, and it's slow - but it's immersive, challenging, and different than anything I've played.GAMEPLAY: Using a standard FPS control scheme, you explore an island searching for the cure to a disease which afflicts you. Symptoms manifest themselves in the form of fatigue (you will drown faster while swimming and lose your footing easier when climbing), suffer from blurry vision, and eventually die. You must stave off these effects by crafting medicines out of plants found on the island, of which there are many types, and you have to collect and research each one to see what it does. You also have to drink water, which you can find in ponds, pitchers in cabins, or in your canteen. Dehydration causes onset of the symptoms above. Strangely, and somewhat jarringly, you don't have to eat at all.Perhaps the most unique aspect of this game is the navigational aspect. You will find small snippets of maps, but most of the mapping will have to be done manually in the form of triangulation - pinpointing your location in relation to two landmarks (statues, cabins, and tents). It's the largest factor in determining your route, as you will be forced to stay within sight of landmarks. It creates a feeling of helplessness and empowerment simultaneously - you will be walking blind with little clue where to go, until you add a little bit more to your map, which is a great feeling every time. Your compass is a vital suplement to the map, as it's easy to become lost. The game doesn't handhold, and when you lose your path, there's little recourse except to take your best guess as to where to go. This is most dangerous when falling, as the screen blurs, you become turned around, and drop whatever items you were carrying. It has the potential to be fatal, especially when in uncharted territory. Another useful tool is your watch, which you must use to ensure you aren't caught in the jungle at night - visibility is extremely limited, to the point where it is almost entirely pointless to travel at night. This is another large factor in determining your travel schedule, as you will want to be in a safe place before nightfall.Of course, there's another danger on the island in the form of a monster that stalks the island, against which you are defenceless. It has the potential to throw off your plans, as getting away from it will be paramount - sometimes necessitating flight into unmarked territory.VISUALS: The game looks very nice. It goes for a realistic style, which looks great for the environment elements - rocks, water, etc. Living creatures look a little stinted, but by no means bad, and certainly not immersion breaking. Reaching the coastline and looking out onto the water is one of the most beautiful parts of this game. While most of the game takes place in nature, there are a few man-made elements that stand out visually - ruins in the jungle, for instance.AUDIO: Serves the game extremely well. There's a soft ambient soundtrack that underlines the experience, making exploring the island strangely calming, despite the need for survival. Sound effects are great too - perhaps the most memorable being the pulsing and ringing that occurs when taking a fall. A sound you will quickly identify is the pounding of the character's heart when the monster approaches, its intensity indicating the creature's proximity. It's a very quiet game, but each sound serves to add a little something to the experience. STORY: The focus is on survival and escaping the island, but there's a tale to be uncovered about the protagonist's past, as well as that of the island - who had been exploring the island and why, and how they came to disappear. It comes off mostly as context for the gameplay, which isn't a bad thing, especially considering the story is satisfying to uncover in all of its little bits and pieces, conveyed almost entirely by optional notes.This game is a slow burn, and has challenges unlike those I've seen in other games. Which is why I enjoyed it so thoroughly - it's a chance to explore a beautiful island on your own, and craft strategies for survival. It's hard to say, exactly, what type of demographic I'd recommend this game to - perhaps horror fans looking for a new angle, or those who like exploration games - but I know that I would for sure, as I had a great time with this game.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												One of the most innovative games outhere. Some people may consider it boring, cause practically everything you do is roaming around and looking for flowers, mushrooms. At the same time you do not have any map and you have to travel very carefully and have to use triangulation technique just to know where you are. Without triangulation usage you will be lost really fast and... eaten. Yes. There's a creature roaming around too. What is more interesting is that this creature is unscripted. It means you can meet it right at the first day. Vice versa you can meet your enemy on day 10 for example. Nevertheless you will meet it eventually, because most of times it's roaming around the most important rare ingridients (flowers-mushrooms). Another one enemy is your own sickness, physical not mental. You're sick, so you have to make hand-made pills regularly. There's also a dehydration, but no starvation for some unknown reasons. Anyway dehydration is not a problem at all, nothing would change without this lively but useless detail. And that's almost everything I can say about game mechanics. The way you can get lost and be frightened is the only one outstanding feature; really big open world created believable and full of points of interest for explorers.As for the story it's all hidden in notes and some photographs. No voices, no scenes, no characters alive. You are all alone (if not to mention the creature). Story is nice, mysterious and a bit detectivish. And by the way it's crucial to collect story notes, otherwise looking for ingridiends will become a pain in the a$$. You do can collect plants blindly, but that's really hard.I would recommend that game to anyone who is not afraid to try something new and unique. It's not expensive, so I really recommend to give it a try.
